PREFACE
   This code of the Village of Sherman, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance 2023-17, passed December 19, 2023. Ordinances of the
Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to
the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the
code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
SHERMAN VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the village board of trustees, this code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official village code of
Sherman. This code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the SHERMAN
VILLAGE CODE and is hereby published by authority of the village board of
trustees and shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation
of the village as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (2010 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The village code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of
this state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect,
except the excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2010 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending the village code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of the
village code. (2010 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Said code, while in
actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and
remain the property of the village and shall be returned to the office of the
village clerk when directed so to do by order of the village board of trustees.
(2010 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the village passed by the president and board of
trustees prior to the adoption of this code are hereby repealed, except such as
are included in this code or are by necessary implication herein reserved from
repeal (subject to the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and
excluding the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
   A.   Tax levy ordinances;
   B.   Appropriation ordinances;
   C.   Ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
   D.   Franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to
persons or corporations;
   E.   Contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants;
   F.   Salary ordinances;
   G.   Ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other
public places;
   H.   Improvement ordinances;
   I.   Bond ordinances;
   J.   Ordinances relating to elections;
   K.   Ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or
from the village; and
   L.   All special ordinances. (2010 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of section
1-2-1 of this chapter, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances with respect to such provisions only. (2010 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the village herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the village under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this code. (2010 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this code or any part thereof is, for any reason, held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this code, or any part thereof. The village board of
trustees hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (2010 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
SECTION:
1-3-1: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the president and village board of trustees may
be fully carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Computation Of Time: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an
act to be done in a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be held,
the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall not be counted
in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall
be counted.
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform
some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   E.   Gender: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be
applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to
males.
   F.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   G.   May; Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is
mandatory.
   H.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   I.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   J.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words "of the village of Sherman".
   K.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   L.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
village has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter",
"section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to village ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2010 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD OF TRUSTEES: Unless otherwise indicated, the village board of trustees of
the village of Sherman.
CODE: The village code of the village of Sherman.
COUNTY: The county of Sangamon, state of Illinois.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the village, or any activity which, by its perpetuation, can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the village.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Sherman, county of Sangamon, state of Illinois.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (2010 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the village code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (2010 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY 1 :
   A.   General Penalty Imposed: Unless specifically provided elsewhere in this
code or state statute, any person found to have been in violation of any of the
terms and provisions of this code shall be fined in an amount not to exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). No imprisonment for failure to pay such
fine, penalty or cost shall exceed six (6) months for each offense. Each day
that a violation continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense. A penalty
for each offense may include a requirement that the offending party perform
some reasonable public service work such as, but not limited to, picking up
litter in public parks or upon public highways or performing maintenance of
public facilities. A violation hereof may be established by a preponderance of
the evidence.
   B.   Acts Consistent With Criminal Laws Of State: If, by the terms of an
ordinance, an act that would be consistent with the criminal laws of the state
is declared to be a misdemeanor, the penalty therefor shall be for a period of
incarceration in a penal institution other than the penitentiary not to exceed
six (6) months. The matter shall be prosecuted under the rules of criminal
procedure of the state, and the village shall be required to establish guilt
beyond a reasonable doubt.
   C.   Limitation; Compliance With Statute: The provisions of subsection A of
this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be greater than that established
by state statute for the same offense. (2010 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1.
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2010 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the village board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2010 Code)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICIAL AND CORPORATE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Official Village Map
1-5-2: Procedure For Requested Information
1-5-1: OFFICIAL VILLAGE MAP:
   A.   A map of the village entitled "official map, village of Sherman,
Sangamon County, Illinois", the most current edition thereof, is hereby
declared to be the official map of the village.
   B.   The original of said map is hereby entrusted to the village clerk who
shall keep the same prominently displayed in his office and readily available
for inspection by members of the public. Copies thereof, properly certified and
dated, may be sold by the clerk at a fee of five dollars ($5.00) each, the
proceeds of which are to be deposited with the village treasurer and accounted
for in the general fund.
   C.   The village clerk is hereby empowered and directed to maintain the map
in a current condition and to record thereon any annexations or disconnections
from the village by marking the same thereon with a distinctive line showing
the boundaries of said annexations or disconnections and, in addition, a
reference to the village ordinance or court decision effectuating the same,
together with the date thereof.
   D.   The map, when certified by the village clerk, shall be prima facie
evidence of the area encompassed by the village and the boundaries thereof.
(1984 Code §
1-7-1)
1-5-2: PROCEDURE FOR REQUESTED INFORMATION:
The purpose of this section is to establish a procedure for the village in
handling requests for information, and the following conditions shall apply:
(1984 Code §
1-8-1)
   A.   All requests for information will be reasonable in nature, and ten (10)
working days will be allowed for the furnishing of said information. (1984 Code
§
1-8-1; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   All requests for information from the public records of the village
shall be directed to the village clerk, and a fee of fifty cents ($0.50) per
page for any documentation furnished will be charged and paid in advance to the
clerk at his office in the village. Should the number or nature of the requests
become extremely time consuming, the village is entitled to charge postage and
a fee for reasonable and necessary time for the assembling and mailing of said
information.
   C.   Any ordinances, resolutions or other documentation published according
to state statute and records of closed meetings of the village board of
trustees will not be furnished, and no requests for automatic mailings of
specific documents will be allowed.
   D.   All requests for information shall be a matter of public record of the
village and shall be directed to the village clerk. The village clerk shall
respond to all such requests in accordance with the Illinois freedom of
information act 1 . (1984 Code §
1-8-1)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Meetings
1-6-2: Compensation
1-6-3: Standing Committees
1-6-1: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Regularly scheduled meetings of the board of trustees
shall be held at the time and date determined by said board of trustees and
posted on the village website.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings of the board of trustees may be
called by the president or by any three (3) members of the board of trustees
from time to time upon not less than forty eight (48) hours' notice to all
members of the board of trustees and upon posting notice of said special
meeting at the site of the regular board of trustees meetings not less than
forty eight (48) hours prior to the time of said special meeting. (1984 Code §
1-5-1; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Adjourned Meetings: Adjourned meetings of the board of trustees may be
held for the purpose of completing unfinished business of the regular meetings
at such times as may be determined by the board of trustees.
   D.   Open Meetings: All meetings of the board of trustees or of any
committees, legislative, executive or administrative bodies thereof shall be
public meetings unless closed pursuant to and in compliance with the open
meetings act 1  or any other similar provision of the laws of the state. (1984
Code §
1-5-1)
   E.   Remote Attendance At Meetings:
      1.   Rules Statement: Any member of the village board may attend any open
or closed meeting of the village board via electronic means (such as by
telephone, video or internet connection) provided that such attendance is not
otherwise prohibited and is in compliance with these rules and any applicable
laws.
      2.   Prerequisites: A member of the village may attend a meeting
electronically if the member meets the following conditions:
         a.   The member must notify the clerk at least twenty four (24) hours
before the meeting, unless impractical, so that necessary communications
equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical
arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote attendance.
         b.   The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why
he or she is unable to physically attend the meeting:
            (1)   The member cannot attend because of personal illness or
disability; or
            (2)   The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or
the business of the village; or
            (3)   The member cannot attend because of a family or other
emergency.
      3.   Authorization To Participate: The clerk, after receiving the
electronic attendance request, shall inform the village of the request for
electronic attendance. After establishing that there is a quorum physically
present at a meeting where a member of the village desires to attend
electronically, the presiding officer shall state that: a) a notice was
received by a member of the village in accordance with these rules, and b) the
member will be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a
motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded, and
approved by two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the village physically present
at the meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion
fails to achieve the required vote by the members of the village physically
present at the meeting, then the request by the member to attend the meeting
electronically shall be deemed approved by the village and the presiding
officer shall declare the requesting member present. After such declaration by
the presiding officer, the question of a member's electronic attendance may not
be reconsidered.
      4.   Adequate Equipment Required: The member participating electronically
and other members of the village must be able to communicate effectively, and
members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting
site. Before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the village shall
provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting site.
      5.   Minutes: Any member attending electronically shall be considered an
off site attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting if the
member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes shall also reflect and state
specifically whether each member is physically present or present by electronic
means.
      6.   Rights Of Remote Member: A member permitted to attend electronically
will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate
in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all
general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to.
The member attending electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as
to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically
shall be called during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded
by the clerk and placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member
attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any
member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her
leaving and returning.
      7.   Committees, Boards And Commissions: These rules shall apply to all
committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the village.
      8.   Participation While Driving Prohibited: Members permitted to attend
a meeting electronically may not participate while driving. Accordingly, if a
member meets all other criteria, but the only available method to attend the
meeting is by use of a cellular phone while driving, the member may not
participate.
      9.   Costs: A member participating remotely via telephone shall be
reimbursed for the cost of the telephone call upon a valid receipt shown. Any
other costs associated with remote participation, including video conferencing
and other audio and video equipment, must be previously approved by the
village.
      10.   Limited Participation Rights: Nothing herein shall prohibit an
official who does not meet the prerequisites of subsection E2 of this section
from participating in the meeting remotely, without voting rights, if the audio
or video equipment is available and a majority of those present do not vote
against the participation. Costs in such circumstances shall not be
reimbursable. (Ord. 2011-18, 11-7-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-6-2: COMPENSATION:
The village president and trustees shall be paid as follows for services
rendered to the village:
   A.   President:
      1.   Base Monthly Salary: The president shall be paid a base monthly
salary of three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      2.   Additional Salary:
         a.   The president shall be paid at the rate of one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each regularly scheduled meeting and each recessed meeting or
special meeting attended during each calendar month, not to exceed three (3)
meetings per month.
         b.   The president shall also be paid twenty dollars ($20.00) per hour
for each hour of work done on village business other than meetings, not to
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per month. No working hours shall be
carried over from month to month if the president works hours in excess of
those required to reach the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      3.   Maximum Salary: In no event shall the total salary paid to the
president exceed the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per month. (Ord.
2002-28, 9-17-2002; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Trustees: Trustees shall be paid a base monthly salary of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00), plus one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) for
each special meeting attended during each calendar month, not to exceed one
special meeting per month. (Ord. 2010-12, 10-5-2010)
   C.   Payment Of Compensation: Fees shall be paid monthly by the village
treasurer, and meeting attendance fees shall be based upon the attendance roll
call as filed with the village clerk. Said fees shall be charged against the
general corporate fund. The village shall reimburse all expenses incurred by
any elected official which are necessary for the performance of the official's
duties as are approved in advance by the village board of trustees. (Ord. 2002-
28, 9-17-2002; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 2010-12, 10-5-2010)

(Ord. 2009-24, 6-16-2009)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
1-7-1: Village Manager And Economic Development Coordinator
1-7-2: Village Attorney
1-7-3: Village Clerk
1-7-4: Village Architect
1-7-5: Other Officers And Employees
1-7-6: Social Security
1-7-1: VILLAGE MANAGER AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COORDINATOR:
   A.   Village Manager: There is hereby created the position of village
manager. The manager shall be appointed by the village president and shall
serve at the president's will. The manager shall report directly to the village
president and shall be responsible for directing the daily activities as set by
the president pertaining to the supervision of department heads, implementation
of short and long term goals, public relations, coordination with other taxing
bodies of the village, and oversight of the budget. Additionally, the manager
shall provide assistance, advice and guidance to the president and board of
trustees which shall facilitate the board's ability to plan for the future,
develop sound policies and procedures, and respond to the citizenry.
   B.   Economic Development Coordinator: There is hereby created the position
of economic development coordinator. The coordinator shall be appointed by the
village president and shall serve at the president's will. The coordinator
shall report directly to the village president and shall be responsible for
establishing and coordinating a sound economic development program through
implementation and use of the powers granted to the village under the state
municipal code and through conducting such research and inventory of resources
and preparation of industrial facts profiles to be used as presentations to
industrial prospects considering expansion or location in the Sherman area. The
economic development coordinator may assist the village president in
negotiations as per the village economic development plan.
   C.   Positions May Be Held By Same Individual; Time Management:
      1.   The positions of village manager and economic development
coordinator may and can be held by the same individual functioning in both
capacities. These position classifications can be budgeted for from various
funds from within the village treasury as set by the village president and
board of trustees. (Ord. 2008-9, 10-7-2008)
      2.   The position of village manager and economic development
coordinator, having been filled by a single qualified individual, requires
direction regarding the allocation of time to be spent on the responsibilities
and duties assigned to each position. After reviewing the respective tasks to
be undertaken by each position, it is hereby determined that no less than sixty
percent (60%) of the workday of the village manager/economic coordinator should
be spent implementing all laws pertaining to economic development and focus
(almost exclusively) on the development and redevelopment of the three (3)
designated "redevelopment project areas" as established by the village board in
accordance with the tax increment allocation redevelopment act, 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-74.1 et seq. (Res. 2008-13, 12-2-2008)
1-7-2: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
There is hereby created the position of village attorney. Said attorney shall
be appointed by the president with the consent of the majority of the board of
trustees. Said attorney is authorized and empowered to represent the village in
all legal matters and to discharge such other duties as may be imposed by law,
or by motion, resolution or ordinance of the board of trustees and to employ,
within the scope of his authority, such legal or technical assistants necessary
to discharge his duties. (1984 Code §
1-6-1)
1-7-3: VILLAGE CLERK:
   A.   Appointment: The position of village clerk shall be filled by
appointment by the village president with the concurrence of a majority of
village trustees then in office as is permitted by 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-25-90(a). The village clerk, once appointed, shall serve at the
pleasure of the village president. (Ord. 2010-11, 10-5-2010)
   B.   Compensation: The village clerk shall be paid the following fees for
attending meetings of the board of trustees:
      1.   Compensation Per Meeting: The compensation per meeting of the
village clerk shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) (regularly scheduled and
special), up to three (3) meetings per month.
      2.   Additional Compensation: As additional compensation, at its
discretion, the village board may employ the village clerk for additional work
on behalf of the village. The village clerk shall be paid at an hourly rate for
additional work performed on behalf of the village. Any additional compensation
paid to the village clerk under this subsection shall be upon terms and
conditions approved by the village board and in compliance with all applicable
state and federal laws. (Ord. 2002-22, 9-3-2002; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 2010-11,
10-5-2010)
1-7-4: VILLAGE ARCHITECT:
   A.   Position Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the position of
village architect. The village architect shall be appointed by the president,
with the consent of the majority of the board of trustees.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The village architect is authorized and empowered to
represent the village in all matters and to discharge such other duties as may
be imposed by law, or by motion, resolution or ordinance of the board of
trustees, including, without limitation, the village beautification program,
any approved TIF assistance programs, internal operations, building code
implementation and inspection processes, and coordination with a designated
architectural control committee.
   C.   Assistants: The village architect is authorized to employ, within the
scope of authority designated by the president or the board of trustees, such
assistants necessary to discharge the duties of office. (Ord. 2009-19, 5-19-
2009)
1-7-5: OTHER OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
The village board shall from time to time appoint, retain or employ such other
officers or employees as it shall deem necessary to carry out the governmental
duties of the village. Rates of compensation and other matters relating to such
employment shall be established by the village board in accord with applicable
statutes and regulations of the state of Illinois and the United States Of
America. (1984 Code §
1-6-2)
1-7-6: SOCIAL SECURITY:
   A.   Policy And Purpose: It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose
of the village to extend to the eligible employees thereof, effective as of
July 1, 1974, the benefits of the federal old age, survivors and disability
insurance provisions of the federal social security act and amendments thereto.
In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the village president shall
take such action as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations.
   B.   Execution Of Agreement With State: The village president is hereby
authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the social security unit
of the state employees' retirement system of Illinois to secure coverage of
eligible employees as provided in this section.
   C.   Withholdings; Remittance: Withholdings from salaries or wages of
employees for the purpose provided in this section are hereby authorized to be
made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state
and federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency in
such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws or regulations.
   D.   Employer Contributions And Administrative Expenses: Employer
contributions and administrative expense shall be paid to the state agency in
accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts appropriated
for such purposes.
   E.   Records And Reports: The village treasurer shall maintain such records
and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws
or regulations. (1984 Code §
1-6-3)
ARTICLE A. PERSONNEL CODE
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Policy Statement
1-7A-2: Definitions
1-7A-3: Position Classification, Job Description And Salary Administration Plan
1-7A-4: Attendance And Leave
1-7A-5: Appointment And Separation
1-7A-6: Probation
1-7A-7: Disciplinary Actions
1-7A-8: Outside Employment
1-7A-9: Gifts And Gratuities
1-7A-10: Resignation
1-7A-11: Records Kept
1-7A-12: Not An Employment Contract
1-7A-13: Saving Clause
1-7A-14: Opting Out Of The Illinois Paid Leave For All Workers Act
1-7A-1: POLICY STATEMENT:
   A.   Equal employment opportunity is the policy in all conditions, terms and
benefits of employment with the village.
   B.   The purpose of this statement is to clearly define the
responsibilities, functions and working relationships of employees of the
village. This statement is designed to promote understanding and efficiency,
and to provide fair and equal opportunities and evaluation to all employees.
Unless an exception is specifically made, these rules shall apply to all
employees of the village but not to elected and appointed officials, or
independent contractors hired by the village.
   C.   All changes must be approved by the village board. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-
1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions apply to this personnel code:
ANNIVERSARY DATE: The date upon which an employee receives his/her permanent
appointment.
APPOINTMENT: Employment with the village of Sherman.
BREAK PERIOD: That part of each day, other than mealtime, allotted an employee.
COMPENSATORY TIME: Authorized time worked in excess of the regular scheduled
workweek. Authorized vacation, sick leave, military leave, jury duty, personal
days and holidays shall not be considered as time worked for purposes of
compensatory time and overtime.
   A.   For police, depending on type of schedule, a workweek will be either
forty eight (48) hours per eight (8) days or eighty four (84) hours per
fourteen (14) days.
   B.   For police administration, a workweek will be forty (40) hours per
seven (7) days, unless needed to work the forty eight (48) hour week.
   C.   For streets, parks and sewers, a workweek will be forty (40) hours per
seven (7) days.
DEMOTION: A transfer of an employee from a position in one class to a position
of less authority and/or less responsibility.
FULL TIME EMPLOYEE: An employee working a forty eight (48) hour (police) or
forty (40) hour (streets, parks and sewers) week who has satisfactorily
completed his/her probationary period and who is eligible for benefits.
IMMEDIATE FAMILY: Husband, wife, son, daughter, father, mother, father-in-law,
mother-in-law, brother, sister, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, grandfather,
grandmother, or other unspecified relatives if they live in the employee's
household.
LAYOFF: A separation from the village because of a lack of operating funds,
abolishment of position, or for other reasons beyond the control of an
employee, and not reflecting unsatisfactory performance on the part of said
employee.
MILITARY LEAVE: A period of training required because of membership in a
reserve unit or active duty in the United States armed forces.
MONTH: One calendar month from the first to the last day of said month.
PART TIME EMPLOYEE: An employee working less than a forty (40) hour week who
has satisfactorily completed his/her probationary period and who is not
eligible for benefits.
PROBATIONARY EMPLOYEE: An employee who has not completed his/her trial service
period of one year.
PROMOTION: Transfer of an employee from one position to another having greater
authority and/or responsibility.
SUPERVISOR: Any person responsible to a higher divisional or department
authority directing the work or training of others.
TEMPORARY EMPLOYEE: An employee who is filling a position for a limited
duration only and is not a probationary employee, and is not entitled to
benefits of full time employees.
TYPES OF EMPLOYMENT STATUS: There are four (4) types of employee status. They
are acquired as follows:
   A.   Full Time: Acquired by an employee who has been retained in his/her
position after the completion of the probationary period as provided in this
policy.
   B.   Probationary: Acquired by an employee who has been appointed, but who
has not completed the probationary period provided in this policy.
   C.   Temporary: Acquired by an employee who has been appointed to complete a
specific project which will last for a limited period of time, and is not a
probationary employee; not to exceed nine hundred ninety nine (999) hours per
year. Example: Summer help.
   D.   Part Time: An employee hired to work less than forty (40) hours a week
and who has satisfactorily completed his/her probationary period. (Ord. 1999-
22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
1-7A-3: POSITION CLASSIFICATION, JOB DESCRIPTION AND SALARY ADMINISTRATION
PLAN:
   A.   Maintenance And Modifications; Copies Available: The village president
and village board shall be responsible for continuous maintenance of the
personnel policies and procedures. Modifications of the personnel policies and
procedures are effective after approval by the village board. Copies of the
personnel policy will be available for public inspection.
   B.   Salaries And Pay Increases: All salaries and pay increases shall be
based upon consideration of budget figures, qualifications, ability,
efficiency, and length of service.
   C.   Contractual Service: With approval of the village board, the village
may contract with independent contractors or parties for the performance of
personal or professional services, and such contracts shall not be subject to
any policies or agreements affecting village employees nor subject to the
provisions of this personnel code.
   D.   Methods Of Payment: Pay periods and rates of payment shall be set by
the village president and village board.
   E.   Preparation Of Payrolls: Payroll sheets will be maintained to show the
name, rate and type of pay and the amount of time for which each individual
employee is paid.
   F.   Residency Of Police Employees: All nonprobationary police employees
shall live within a fifteen (15) minute response time of the village. All
addresses are required to be recorded with the department. Changes in addresses
shall be reported within fourteen (14) hours of the change. If an officer moves
out of the fifteen (15) minute response zone without express written consent of
the village board, automatic termination of employment results, unless there is
a temporary emergency approved by the chief of police. Provided however, the
village board may, for good cause shown, waive the residency requirements of
this subsection. Any such waiver shall be at the sole discretion of the village
board and upon such terms and conditions as the board may deem appropriate, and
such waiver may be withdrawn or rendered ineffective upon six (6) months'
written notice to the officer receiving such waiver.
   G.   Change In Personal Status: Employees of the village shall report all
changes in dependent status, residence, telephone number, etc., during their
next scheduled workday following. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-4: ATTENDANCE AND LEAVE:
   A.   Hours Of Work:
      1.   Nonpolice Personnel: Normal working hours for full time nonpolice
personnel shall be an eight (8) hour working day. Each employee shall be
entitled to a one hour lunch period to be taken approximately at midshift as
scheduled by the department head to be taken in addition to the eight (8) hour
workday. Each employee will have regularly scheduled off days, and may be
rescheduled, in case of need, subject to mutual consent. All full time
employees are subject to be on twenty four (24) hour call, when available.
      2.   Police Personnel:
         a.   Normal working hours for police supervisors and/or officers
scheduled to an eight (8) hour working day shall be entitled to a one hour
lunch period to be taken approximately at midshift. Each officer scheduled to
an eight (8) hour workday will have regularly scheduled off days. All full time
employees are subject to be on twenty four (24) hour call, when available.
         b.   Normal working hours for police personnel shall be a twelve (12)
hour working day. Each employee shall be entitled to a one hour lunch period to
be taken in his twelve (12) hour workday. Each employee shall be entitled to a
one hour paperwork period in the office during his twelve (12) hour workday.
Each employee shall be entitled to three (3) 15-minute break periods during his
twelve (12) hour workday. Each employee will have regularly scheduled off days,
and may be rescheduled in case of need. All full time employees are subject to
be on twenty four (24) hour call, when available.
   B.   Attendance: Employees shall be at their places of work in accordance
with these rules and general regulations. Departments shall maintain attendance
records of employees as necessary or as required by the village board.
   C.   Emergency Service: Whenever a condition exists that is deemed by each
individual department head or the village president to be of an emergency
nature, regular tours may be extended and/or days off, furloughs and leaves of
absence of any or all village personnel may be canceled.
   D.   Absence From Work Without Report: Every village employee who fails to
appear for duty at the date, time and place specified for so doing without the
consent of competent authority is "absent without leave". Such absences must be
reported, as soon as they are noted, to the department head or village
president.
   E.   Overtime: Full time employees shall work overtime only when authorized
by the departmental head, supervisor, and/or village president. "Overtime" is
defined as working more than forty (40) hours in a calendar week or, in the
case of police personnel, depending on type of schedule, working more than
forty eight (48) hours in an eight (8) day work period or eighty four (84)
hours in a fourteen (14) day work period. Overtime work shall be compensated
through payment at time and a half the regular hourly rate. For alternative
compensatory time, refer to subsection H of this section. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-
1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
   F.   Authorized Holidays:
      1.    Holidays Enumerated:
         a.   Generally:
            New Year's Day
            Good Friday
            Memorial Day
            July 4
            Labor Day
            Thanksgiving Day
            Christmas Day
         b.   Union Employees: Union employee holidays are governed by their
union contract. (2010 Code)
      2.   Policy:
         a.   Regular Full Time Employees: Regular full time employees shall
have time off, with full salary payment, on the holidays listed in subsection
F1 of this section.
         b.   Full Time Police Personnel: Full time police personnel that work
an authorized holiday shall be compensated at time and a half the regular
hourly rate. Full time police personnel that do not work shall be compensated
at the regular hourly rate.
         c.   Other Employees: All other village employees shall have the
holidays listed in subsection F1 of this section off.
      3.   Easter Sunday: Easter Sunday shall be observed on the Friday before
for all village employees other than police.
   G.   Vacation Time:
      1.   Time Established: Full time village employees will be allowed
vacation time as follows:
         a.   After successfully completing one year probation, full time
employees will then be allowed to accrue two (2) weeks of vacation time.
Thereafter, vacation time accrues on a monthly basis.
         b.   After the full time employee has worked five (5) consecutive
years for the village, said employee will accrue three (3) weeks' vacation
time.
         c.   After the full time employee has worked ten (10) consecutive
years for the village, said employee will accrue four (4) weeks' vacation time.
         d.   After the full time employee has worked twenty (20) consecutive
years for the village, said employee will accrue five (5) weeks' vacation time.
      2.   Accumulations: Full time employees will be allowed to accumulate two
(2) years' vacation time. Examples: Employees with three (3) years' service
would only be able to carry four (4) weeks into their fourth year of service;
employees with six (6) years' service would only be able to carry six (6) weeks
into their seventh year of service.
      3.   Eligibility: Employees wishing to take vacation time must request
this vacation time in writing at least one month prior to the dates the
employee wishes to take off. Requests will be approved at the discretion of the
department head. Requests for the same date will be approved by seniority
within each rank. The one month requirement may be waived by the department
head for emergency situations on a case by case basis.
      4.   Compensation For Vacation Credits Upon Termination: Salary payment
will be made in lieu of vacation leave not taken upon termination.
   H.   Compensatory Time Off: At the discretion of the supervisor, full time
employees may be granted compensatory time off equal to one and one-half (11/2)
times the number of overtime hours worked. No employee may accrue more than
eighty (80) hours of compensatory time at any one point in time. Overtime work
in excess of this limit must be compensated in cash. An employee shall be
compensated in cash for compensatory time remaining unused at the time of
termination of his employment, to be paid at a rate based upon the average rate
of pay received by the employee during the previous three (3) years, or at the
final regular rate received by the employee, whichever is higher. An employee
can utilize accrued compensatory time within a reasonable period of requesting
its use so long as the use is not unduly disruptive. Compensatory time may be
used in conjunction with vacation leave and may be taken only when scheduled
ahead of time, with approval of the department head and/or village president.
The provisions of this subsection shall be subject to the requirements of the
fair labor standards act and any other applicable state or federal law.
   I.   Leave Of Absence: "Leave of absence" is time off without pay. All such
leaves are subject to approval of the department head and village board. Leave
of absence can only be taken when all vacation and compensatory time has been
used, except in the case of employees under military orders.
   J.   Military Leave: There shall be granted up to fifteen (15) days of leave
for military training or special duty to employees who are members of a reserve
component of the United States armed forces. The village will compensate any
difference in pay if military pay is less than the regular rate of pay for that
employee. Any leave beyond this increment of time would come under subsection I
of this section. Subject to applicable federal law, the employee using military
leave shall be responsible to furnish his/her department head a copy of the
orders necessitating the military leave.
   K.   Retirement Plan: All full time employees of the village will receive
the deferred compensation plan that the village provides.
   L.   Jury Duty: Any employee who is called for jury duty shall be allowed
time away from work with pay for such purposes. In cases where there is
compensation, said employee will be paid the difference between the
compensation received and his/her regular rate of pay.
   M.   Sick Leave: All permanent full-time employees shall receive one sick
day per month, twelve (12) per year. Sick days must be used for actual illness
or injury preventing an employee from being able to work. Employees absent in
excess of three (3) consecutive days must present a physician's note or report.
Sick leave may be used in case of the illness of the immediate family of the
employee, (spouse, domestic partner, children, step-children, parents, step-
parents, in-laws, and paternal and maternal grandparents).
   N.   Personal Day: Personal days may be taken after probation, with good
cause and approval of the department head and the village president, not to
exceed three (3) days per year and not to be considered as vacation days.
   O.   Disability:
      1.   Definition: "Disability" is defined as a physical or medical
condition which prohibits the employee from acceptably performing the job
duties assigned to him/her.
      2.   Determination Of Disability: Disabilities may result from disease,
injury, congenital condition of birth, functional disorder, or pregnancy. The
ability of an employee to adequately perform the job duties assigned to him/her
shall be determined by the village board after consultation with the department
head. Before so determining, the village board shall make every reasonable
effort to accommodate the employee by job restructuring or the like without
incurring unreasonable expense or unduly disrupting the conduct of village
business.
   P.   Physical Examination: An employee who is seeking sick leave or
disability leave shall be required, if requested by the village board, to
submit himself/herself, at the expense of the village, for an examination to a
duly qualified medical practitioner or surgeon selected by the village, at any
time and place reasonably convenient for the employee, for the purpose of
determining the nature, extent and probable duration of the illness or injury
to the employee. The village will make every effort to provide a reasonable
accommodation when deemed necessary by qualified medical authority.
   Q.   Alcohol And Drug Policy: All village employees shall comply with the
laws of the United States and the state of Illinois and the ordinances of the
village with respect to alcohol and drugs and shall refrain from the abuse of
said substances. Members of the police department shall abide by the department
policy with respect to alcohol and drugs. No alcohol nor any drug which might
impair an employee's performance shall be consumed during working hours nor
shall any village employee report for work impaired by alcohol or drugs in such
a manner as to be unable to properly and efficiently perform the employee's
duties.
   R.   Performance And Development Review:
      1.   A performance and development review will be conducted at least once
annually for all full time employees of the village. The employee's supervisor
will conduct the review. The purpose of the review is to evaluate employee job
performance and development; to establish strengths and development needs of
the individual employee; and to provide information and evaluation to the
individual employee about that employee's job performance. The review will be
in writing and will be documented by the supervisor and signed by said
supervisor. The review form will provide a comments section for both the
supervisor and the employee. The document will be placed in the employee's
personnel file. The initial employee evaluations shall be completed on or
before March 1, 2005, and annually thereafter by March 1.
      2.   New employees on probation will be reviewed and evaluated thirty
(30) days prior to the expiration of their probationary period for the purposes
stated in subsection R1 of this section and for purposes of evaluating their
continued employment with the village. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999;
amd. Ord. 2004-22, 6-1-2004; Ord. 2017-1, 1-10-2017)
1-7A-5: APPOINTMENT AND SEPARATION:
   A.   Medical Examination May Be Required: As a condition of any type of
employment, an employee may be required to undergo a medical examination by a
physician approved by the village and at the expense of the village.
   B.   Appointment: A personnel committee, appointed by the village board,
shall have direct responsibility for the review and recommendation to the
village board for approval of all village full time and part time employees. In
carrying out this responsibility, the personnel committee can use recognized
professional consultative employment resources and will consult with department
heads in evaluating qualifications. Employment of staff shall be upon the basis
of qualifications and demonstrated competence and skill for the specific
position to be filled and shall be in accordance with state and federal
regulations.
   C.   Bridged Service:
      1.   An employee who leaves employment with the village but returns
within a one year period may use the prior service in determining vacation
time.
      2.   An employee who leaves employment with the village and returns after
a one year period may bridge all previous service after completion of an
additional five (5) years of employment. Vacation time will then be based on
the bridged years of service.
   D.   Layoffs: The village board may lay employees off when they feel such
action is necessary because of a shortage of funds, abolishment of a position,
or for other reasons beyond the control of the concerned employee and not
reflecting discredit on said employee. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-6: PROBATION:
   A.   Definition: The "probationary period" is a working test period when a
newly appointed employee, or an employee whose probationary status arises out
of subsection 1-7A-7C of this article or a current employee promoted to a new
position, is required to demonstrate his/her fitness for a position by actual
performance of the duties of the appointed position.
   B.   Length Of Time: Probationary period shall be for one year or three
hundred sixty five (365) days for new employees and six (6) months for
appointments and promotions of current full time employees.
   C.   Conclusion Of Probation; Procedure: Following the conclusion of the
employee's probationary period, the department head shall either recommend the
employee for continued employment on a nonprobationary basis, or in the case of
a new employee or an employee whose probation arose out of subsection 1-7A-7C
of this article, that the employee not be retained as an employee. In the case
of an employee whose probationary status arises out of employee promotion, then
the department head shall recommend either that the employee be retained at the
new position or returned to the employee's former position. Should the
recommendation be for retention, then the employee will be employed on a
nonprobationary basis upon approval by the village board. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-
1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-7: DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS:
   A.   Duty Of Employees: It shall be the duty of all employees to maintain
high standards of cooperation, efficiency and cost effectiveness in carrying
out their duties and responsibilities as a village employee and to conduct
themselves at all times in a manner so as to not bring themselves or the
village into discredit or disrepute. All employees shall abide by the terms of
the Drug and Alcohol Policy adopted by reference as if laid out herein.
Supervisory staff of the Village shall distribute the policy to all village
employees.
   B.   Working Relationships: Supervisors shall be charged with properly
instructing and organizing persons under supervision so as to create the
greatest degree of cooperation, efficiency and economy. Whenever any question
arises concerning the validity of an order given by a supervisor or other
employee of authority, the employee concerned shall carry out the instructions.
If for any reason the employee deems this work unlawful, hazardous and/or
unsafe, the employee may refuse to do it. In refusing to do the work, the
employee must file a written statement giving reasons for refusal. Also, the
employee must file a written grievance with the department head, who will then
take action by either determining applicable policy to apply to such tasks in
the future, or by referring it back to the village board for action.
   C.   Suspension And Dismissal:
      1.   Suspension:
         a.   Authority To Suspend:
            (1)   A supervisor may suspend an employee for a period of not
longer than four (4) working days for disciplinary reasons. The village board
shall be notified as soon as possible, in writing, of the suspension and shall
decide within thirty (30) days whether the suspension shall be with or without
pay.
            (2)   The village board may suspend with or without pay any village
employee for disciplinary reasons for a period of up to thirty (30) consecutive
calendar days or, if the suspension arises out of an arrest or charge of a
criminal offense, until the arrest and charge is judicially resolved.
         b.   Notice, Reply And Hearing: No suspension in excess of four (4)
working days or dismissal for disciplinary reasons shall be carried out without
approval by the village board after a hearing, prior to which the employee
shall be notified in writing of the proposed action by the village board. The
notice to the employee shall contain a description of the reasons for the
proposed discipline and of the event or actions which precipitated the request
for discipline. The notice shall also contain the time and date of the hearing,
which shall be not less than ten (10) days subsequent to the date of issuance
of the notice. An employee shall have the right to submit a written reply to
the charges for consideration by the village board and may appear at the
hearing with or without counsel to answer to the disciplinary charges.
      2.   Review Of Discipline:
         a.   Any employee disciplined by the village board shall have the
right to submit in writing to the board a request for reconsideration of the
disciplinary action, together with written reasons for said request, and such
request for reconsideration shall be acted upon by the village board within
thirty (30) days of the date of receipt of the request for reconsideration.
Further hearings may be held at the discretion of the village board.
         b.   Requests for review of discipline which does not involve
suspension or discharge may be made by any aggrieved employee to the village
board by submitting a request in writing with written reasons for said request
to the village board. The village board shall act upon said request within
thirty (30) days from the date of its receipt and may, at its discretion, hold
a hearing to review the evidence and arguments of the employee and the
supervisor involved in the disciplinary action.
      3.   Types Of Discipline:
         a.   Discipline shall include the following:
            (1)   Counseling.
            (2)   Oral reprimand.
            (3)   Written reprimand.
            (4)   Suspension up to thirty (30) days in a twelve (12) month
period.
            (5)   Dismissal.
         b.   Discipline in each case shall be imposed as the facts and
circumstances of such case shall warrant and may not necessarily follow the
order of discipline sanctions set forth in subsection C3a of this section.
(Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
      4.   Application Of Suspension And Dismissal Provisions: This subsection
applies to all village employees including police officers; provided, however
that police officers may be disciplined for violation of any of the matters
contained in the police department rules and regulations. Any officer or
department member guilty of violating department rules and regulations shall be
subject to discipline as set forth in said rules and regulations. (Ord. 1999-
22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   Causes For Disciplinary Action Up To And Including Dismissal: Causes
for counseling, verbal/written reprimands, suspension or dismissal shall be,
but not necessarily restricted to:
      1.   Violation of any federal or state law, county or municipal ordinance
or department policy.
      2.   Habitual absence from or tardiness for work without following
established procedures.
      3.   Unlawful, careless, or negligent use of any weapon.
      4.   Failure to follow orders of an authorized supervisor.
      5.   Being wasteful of property, material, or work time, i.e., sleeping
on duty.
      6.   Inefficiency in assigned work.
      7.   Conduct on or off the job which is not becoming to an employee of
the village.
      8.   Unauthorized release of privileged or confidential information.
      9.   Inability to cooperate with fellow employees.
      10.   Hindering other employees in carrying out assigned work.
      11.   Accepting gratuities, nepotism, or conflict of interest.
      12.   Failure to maintain satisfactory credit rating which might cause
undue embarrassment to the village.
      13.   Unacceptable work habits, attitudes, job performance or personal
conduct.
      14.   Associating or conducting business with individuals of unsavory
reputations, criminal records or organized crime syndicate affiliations.
      15.   Publicly criticizing official actions of a superior.
      16.   Failure to notify a superior officer that an employee of the
village is guilty of violating a rule, regulation or order of the department.
      17.   Any other act or omission contrary to good order and discipline of
the village.
   E.   Review Procedure; Nondismissal Grievances: The following procedures
shall provide for consideration and adjustment of any grievance of an employee
other than a dismissal or suspension:
      1.   Employee will consult with his/her immediate supervisor.
      2.   Failing to arrive at a satisfactory settlement, the matter will then
be reviewed by all parties concerned with the immediate supervisor.
      3.   Failing to arrive at a satisfactory settlement, the matter will then
be referred to the trustee in charge of said department.
      4.   Failing to reach a settlement in conference with the trustee in
charge of said department, the employee concerned or his/her authorized agent
may then submit a written statement of grievance to the village board within
ten (10) working days from the day of the conference with the trustee in charge
of said department.
   F.   Village Board Review Of Grievance:
      1.   Upon receipt of a statement of grievance, the village board shall
set a date for a hearing to be held within ten (10) days of receipt of the
statement. The hearing shall be closed to the general public, but the affected
employee may be represented by an attorney and may present witnesses if he/she
wishes to do so. The affected employee may have the hearing transcribed by a
court reporter at his/her expense.
      2.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the village board shall make a
ruling on the grievance presented to them.
      3.   Those empowered by subsection C of this section to suspend and
initiate the dismissal of employees may not remove a full time employee from
performing his/her duties for disciplinary reasons without declaring the
employee suspended or beginning the dismissal process with regard to the
employee pursuant to subsection C of this section. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999,
eff. 8-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2020-04, 2-18-2020)
1-7A-8: OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT:
Full time employees may not carry on, concurrently with their employment by the
village, any secondary employment, private business or undertaking without
first obtaining approval by the trustee in charge of said department or the
village president. The trustee and/or village president may seek input from the
employee's supervisor before making a decision and shall not grant permission
for any secondary employment, private business or undertaking which is not
conducive to the overall image of the village. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff.
8-1-1999)
1-7A-9: GIFTS AND GRATUITIES:
The village policy with respect to gifts and gratuities to village employees
shall be governed by the state officials and employees ethics act 1  and
article B of this chapter. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999; amd. 2010
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq.
1-7A-10: RESIGNATION:
An employee who voluntarily leaves the service of the village shall, except in
emergency circumstances, give advance notice of not less than ten (10) working
days. Notice should be given to the department head and the village president.
Exit interviews will be conducted by the village president and board member(s)
designated by the village president. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-11: RECORDS KEPT:
The village clerk shall maintain all records necessary to the proper
administration of the personnel program. Employee records may be disclosed as
required by the freedom of information act 1  or pursuant to lawful subpoena or
other requirement of law or statute. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
 
Notes
1 2. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
1-7A-12: NOT AN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT:
The village reserves the right to amend, alter, repeal or rescind any and all
provisions of this personnel code at its discretion at any time. The enactment
of this personnel code is in no way intended to nor does it create any
employment contract between the village and any employee covered by the
provisions of this personnel code. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-1999)
1-7A-13: SAVING CLAUSE:
This personnel code shall be deemed to include any law, statute or regulation
of the United States of America and the state of Illinois applicable to
municipalities and their employees in the employment context not specifically
incorporated herein. Any such law, statute or regulation shall nevertheless be
deemed incorporated herein by reference. In the event that this personnel code
is in conflict with any law, statute or regulation of the United States of
America or the state of Illinois, the law, statute or regulation shall be
deemed controlling. In the event that any section or portion of this personnel
code shall be deemed void or unconstitutional by any court of the United States
or the state of Illinois, the remainder of the personnel code shall
nevertheless remain in full force and effect and shall be enforced and
enforceable to the extent permitted by law. (Ord. 1999-22, 6-15-1999, eff. 8-1-
1999)
1-7A-14: OPTING OUT OF THE ILLINOIS PAID LEAVE FOR ALL WORKERS ACT:
   A.   The Village hereby adopts its current paid leave policy for all Village
employees as set forth in the Village's Code of Ordinances, Employee Handbook,
Annual Salary Ordinances, any collective bargaining agreements to which the
Village is a party and all other binding legislative actions governing paid
leave adopted by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village, as the
same may be amended from time to time. However, in no event shall the Village,
as an employer, provide less than one (1) day of paid leave per year to any
Village employee.
   B.   Pursuant to the Village's home rule authority, the Village hereby
declares that the Village, as an employer, is exempt from the requirements of
the Paid Leave for All Workers Act (820 ILCS 192/1 et seq.). The Village as an
employer, shall have no additional obligations with regard to mandatory paid
leave, including, without limitation, any obligations provided under the Act,
except those obligations required by federal and/or state law which validly
preempt the Village's home rule authority.
   C.   Repeal Of Conflicting Provisions: All ordinances, resolutions, and
policies or parts thereof, in conflict with the provisions of this section are,
to the extent of the conflict, expressly repealed on the effective date of this
section.
   D.   Severability: If any provision of this section or application thereof
to any person or circumstance is ruled unconstitutional or otherwise invalid,
such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this
section that can be given effect without the invalid application or provision,
and each invalid provision or invalid application of this section is severable.
(Ord. 2023-16, 12-19-2023)
ARTICLE B. ETHICS
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Definitions
1-7B-2: Prohibited Political Activities
1-7B-3: Gift Ban
1-7B-4: Ethics Advisor
1-7B-5: Penalties
1-7B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to
influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual
to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political
organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities: a) relating to the
support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administration action;
b) relating to collective bargaining; or c) that are otherwise in furtherance
of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination
or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy
in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a
"regular election", as defined in section 1-3 of the election code, 10 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-3.
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section
3 of the Illinois public labor relations act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 315/
3.
COMPENSATED TIME: With respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited
to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as
a condition of his or her employment but, for purposes of this article, does
not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time,
compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence.
With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated
time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the
control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is
executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee
to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work
time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of
the election code, 10 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-1.4.
EMPLOYEE: A person employed by the village, whether on a full time or part time
basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and
control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is
to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor.
EMPLOYER: The village of Sherman.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash,
food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or
attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or
employee.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive: a)
compensation for employment; b) service credit towards pension benefits; and c)
health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by
statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for
service in his or her official capacity.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any
campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not
include activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive,
legislative, or administrative action; b) relating to collective bargaining; or
c) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other
organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or the county clerk under
section 9-3 of the election code, 10 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-3, but only
with respect to those activities that require filing with the state board of
elections or the county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY:
   A.   Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting,
political rally, political demonstration, or other political event.
   B.   Soliciting contributions including, but not limited to, the purchase
of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political
fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event.
   C.   Soliciting, planning the solicitation of or preparing any document or
report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution.
   D.   Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   E.   Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in
an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political
purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   F.   Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political
organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   G.   Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a
political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in
an effort to get voters to the polls.
   H.   Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or
filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or
against any referendum question.
   I.   Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in
that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
   J.   Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes.
   K.   Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign
literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any
candidate for elective office, or for or against any referendum question.
   L.   Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   M.   Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against
any referendum question.
   N.   Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party
convention.
   O.   Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any
election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action: 1) by an officer; or 2) by an employee; or
3) by the officer or another employee directing that employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the officer; or 2) with
an employee; or 3) with the officer or another employee directing that
employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the officer; or 2) by an employee;
or 3) by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the officer or employee.
VILLAGE: The village of Sherman, Illinois. (Ord. 2004-13, 5-4-2004; amd. 2010
Code)
1-7B-2: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited
political activity during any "compensated time", as defined in section
1-7B-1 of this article. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any
property or resources of the village in connection with any prohibited
political activity.
   B.   At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any
other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as
part of that officer's or employee's duties; 2) as a condition of employment;
