CHAPTER 4
CONSTRUCTION OF IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
11-4-1: Notices To Engineer
11-4-2: Inspections Generally
11-4-3: Presence Of Certain Persons During Construction
11-4-4: Pavement Cores
11-4-5: Final Inspection; Deficiencies
11-4-6: As Built Plans
11-4-1: NOTICES TO ENGINEER:
   A.   Construction: The engineer for the village shall be notified at least
forty eight (48) hours prior to commencement of construction. The notification
of construction shall include a written notice of the start of construction
date and an oral discussion with the engineer for the village concerning the
proposed construction plan and schedule. (1984 Code § 6-7-1)
   B.   Plan And Schedule Changes: The engineer for the village shall be
notified in writing of any changes to the proposed plan of construction or
schedule at least twenty four (24) hours before the changes are implemented.
(1984 Code § 6-7-2)
11-4-2: INSPECTIONS GENERALLY:
   A.   Right Of Inspection; Stop Work Order: The village reserves the right to
inspect the progress of the construction work to ensure the approved plans and
specifications are being followed. The subdivider/contractor will be notified
with a stop order of any work found to be unacceptable subsequent to inspection
(s) by village representative(s). Proceeding in violation of a stop order is a
violation of this title. (1984 Code § 6-7-3)
   B.   Inspection Of Materials; Certificates: Materials to be used on the job
may be subject to inspection at the source or at the construction site.
Construction work may be inspected at the time of construction and also
following construction. All material which becomes a permanent part of the
subdivision improvements must be certified, by the manufacturer or by tests, to
meet specifications. Documentation of these certifications is the
responsibility of the subdivider's engineer. (1984 Code § 6-7-6)
11-4-3: PRESENCE OF CERTAIN PERSONS DURING CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   The subdivider's engineer shall have a full time, qualified resident
observer present on the construction site for the following:
      1.   Approval of the subgrade prior to paving.
      2.   Continuous observation of all phases of the paving operation,
construction of sanitary sewer mains and appurtenances, and construction of
storm sewers and appurtenances. (1984 Code § 6-7-4)
   B.   The subdivider's contractor shall have a superintendent on the job site
at all times while construction is in progress. The superintendent shall be
responsible for the entire construction procedure. In his absence, the
superintendent shall indicate to the subdivider's observer the person
temporarily responsible for the conduct of the work. (1984 Code § 6-7-5)
11-4-4: PAVEMENT CORES:
Newly constructed pavements shall be cored at the subdivider's expense. Two (2)
cores shall be provided every five hundred feet (500') on alternative sides of
the pavement to check the thickness of the paving. Location of the cores to be
taken shall be as directed by the engineer for the village. If thin pavement
sections are discovered, additional cores shall be taken to determine the
extent of the thin area(s). (1984 Code § 6-7-7)
11-4-5: FINAL INSPECTION; DEFICIENCIES:
   A.   The subdivider and/or his engineer, in the accompaniment of the
engineer for the village, shall make a final inspection of all improvements
constructed in conjunction with the subdivision to determine final acceptance
by the village. (1984 Code § 6-7-8)
   B.   If the final inspection indicates no deficient items, the village shall
take formal action to accept the completed streets for maintenance. (1984 Code
§ 6-7-9)
   C.   Should any item need correction or repair, the subdivider will be
notified in writing of each deficiency. No street(s) will be accepted in a
subdivision until all streets comply with the village requirements to the
satisfaction of the engineer for the village and the trustee for public works.
   D.   Should the subdivider fail to properly correct any of the deficiencies,
he shall be responsible for all maintenance until such time as the streets are
completely acceptable to the village. Under this situation, the subdivider's
maintenance responsibility shall be construed to include, but not be limited
to, snow and ice control, regular mowing of the parkways, periodic cleaning of
storm sewers and catch basins, etc. Should the subdivider fail to discharge any
of these responsibilities, he will be notified to rectify the situation(s) by
the village clerk. Failure to take the necessary remedial action(s) within
thirty (30) calendar days after such notification may result in a fine not to
exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) with a similar such fine for every
fourteen (14) calendar day period beyond the initial thirty (30) days during
which the necessary repairs/maintenance activities are not completed. (1984
Code § 6-7-9; amd. 2010 Code)
   E.   It should be noted that regardless of whether or not the street(s) has
been accepted by the village for maintenance, no occupancy permits shall be
issued for any residential structure(s) until such time as the builder has
cleaned all debris and mud from the pavement, gutter, etc., in the nearby
vicinity of the subject structure. (1984 Code § 6-7-9)
11-4-6: AS BUILT PLANS:
Subsequent to the satisfactory inspection of the completed improvements, the
subdivider shall have prepared a set of as built plans for each of the
improvements constructed. Such plans shall show all public facilities as built
on the surface and underground, both on public property and on easements, and
shall also indicate all private utility locations that are known. The as built
plans shall carry the seal of a registered professional engineer, who shall
certify that construction was completed and material used was in conformance
with the plans and specifications. These plans shall be submitted to the
village clerk within sixty (60) days of the date of the final inspection. (1984
Code § 6-7-10)
CHAPTER 5
DESIGN AND LAYOUT STANDARDS
SECTION:
11-5-1: General Requirements
11-5-2: Lots
11-5-3: Subdivision Layout
11-5-4: Street And Alley Improvements
11-5-5: Drainage And Storm Sewers
11-5-6: Grading And Clearing
11-5-7: Water Distribution System
11-5-8: Sanitary Sewer Facilities
11-5-9: Appendices
11-5-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Streets, storm drainage, sanitary sewer systems, and water treatment
and distribution represent the four (4) major public investments in a
community. Obviously, these improvements should be permanent enduring assets to
a community. In order to assure that these improvements in a subdivision are
worthy of acceptance by the village, this chapter sets forth the appropriate
design and construction standards necessary to achieve that goal.
   B.   The design and improvement standards set forth herein shall be deemed
minimum requirements for public health, safety, and general welfare. Nothing
contained in these standards shall be construed to mean that the subdivider
cannot construct additional improvements of a higher quality.
   C.   Any tract of land that is unsuitable for development due to probable
flooding, poor drainage, rough topography, adverse soil conditions, excessive
noise, or other conditions, which, in the opinion of the village board, will
prove detrimental to the health, safety and/or general welfare of future
inhabitants of that tract and/or adjacent parcels shall not be subdivided
unless the developer formulates plans/methods which the village board deems
adequate to solve the potential problems engendered by said adverse land
conditions.
   D.   The standards and requirements of this chapter shall apply to all new
subdivisions of land, and they shall be interpreted to encourage and facilitate
better physical quality of land development in the village. (1984 Code § 6-8-1)
   E.   The use of jetting for trench backfill for the construction of sewers,
water main, or other utilities shall be prohibited. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-5-2: LOTS:
   A.   Monuments: Reference monuments shall be set, in the field, at the
corners of all lots platted in accordance with the plat act, 765 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 205/0.01 et seq., as amended from time to time. (1984 Code §
6-8-2; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Size And Configuration:
      1.   Lot Size: All lots shall have the minimum width and areas required
by the village zoning ordinance; except, that where on site sewage disposal is
proposed, the following additional requirements regarding lot width and area
must be observed to protect the public health and welfare: lots for single-
family detached dwellings shall have a minimum size of twenty thousand (20,000)
square feet (excluding easements) and a minimum lot frontage of one hundred
feet (100') at the building line, provided the subdivider can prove to the
satisfaction of the planning committee that the soil and the lot area for the
septic system is suitable for the absorption of septic tank effluent without
contamination of any drinking water supply or creating undesirable sanitary
conditions. The soil must have an acceptable percolation rate without
interference from groundwater or impervious strata below the level of the
absorption system. In every such case, the septic system shall conform to the
requirements of the Illinois department of public health in effect at the time
of the submission of the preliminary plan. Unless these conditions are met, the
engineer for the village may deem that the site is unsuitable for subsurface
sewage disposal systems.
      2.   Building Setbacks: The building setback lines shall conform to the
front yard and side yard setback lines set forth in the village zoning
ordinance.
      3.   Through Lots: Double frontage lots shall not be permitted except by
planning committee approval in instances where: a) lots back upon a
thoroughfare; and b) topographic or other conditions make subdividing otherwise
unreasonable, then such double frontage lots shall have an additional depth of
at least twenty feet (20') for a protective screen planting on one frontage.
Every lot having multiple frontages (e.g., corner lots, through lots) shall be
large enough to permit compliance with the zoning ordinance front setback
requirement on every side of the lot abutting a street.
      4.   Length/Width Ratio: Generally, in the interest of "good planning",
the length of any lot should not be greater than three (3) times the width of
said lot, unless topography or other conditions dictate otherwise.
      5.   Lot Remnants: All lot remnants shall be added to adjacent lots to
avoid the creation of nonconforming lots.
      6.   Relationship Of Side Lot Lines To Street Lines: All side lot lines
should be approximately at right angles to straight street right of way lines
and radial to curved street right of way lines except where a deviation from
this rule will result in a better street/lot design. Along curvilinear street
lines, side lines of lots formed by converging radial projections shall form a
lot having not less than twenty feet (20') across the rear property line.
      7.   Access: Land shall be subdivided in such away that each lot has
direct access to a public street.
      8.   Satisfactory Building Sites: The design and arrangement of lots
should be such that each lot will provide a satisfactory building site. Lots
abutting upon watercourses, drainageways, channels, or streams shall have an
additional depth or width as required to provide an acceptable building site.
   C.   Natural/Historical Features: Whenever any tract is to be subdivided,
the most restrictive measures consistent with the anticipated development of
the tract should be taken to protect such natural features as tree growth,
wetlands, steep slopes, watercourses, and any historically or archaeologically
significant structures/sites.
   D.   Numbering Lots: Lots shall be numbered consecutively throughout all
phases or additions of the subdivision, and the same basic subdivision name
shall be given to all parts thereof. (1984 Code § 6-8-2)
11-5-3: SUBDIVISION LAYOUT:
   A.   Sizes Of Blocks: In residential subdivisions, blocks shall not be less
than four hundred feet (400') nor more than one thousand two hundred feet
(1,200') in length, measured along the greatest dimensions of the enclosed
block area. Blocks shall be wide enough to allow lots of minimum depth of one
hundred feet (100').
   B.   Street Plan:
      1.   General Requirements: The arrangement, character, extension, width
and location of all streets shall be considered in their relationship to
existing and planned streets; to reasonable circulation of traffic within the
subdivision and adjoining lands; to topographic conditions; to runoff of
stormwater; to public convenience and safety; and in their appropriate
relationship to the proposed uses of the area to be served. It is the policy of
the village to encourage internal circulation in new subdivisions. Plats
showing single lot access to state/county highways will not be approved without
written assurance from the state/county highway department that access permits
will be granted.
      2.   Plan/Profile Specifications: Contained below in table 5.1 are the
minimum street specifications that apply specifically to residential
subdivisions. At the recommendation of the engineer for the village, the
village board may require higher standards consistent with accepted engineering
practices for streets in nonresidential subdivisions. Appropriate street
classifications shall be determined and/or verified by the engineer for the
village and/or village board at the time of submittal of the preliminary plat.
   TABLE 5.1: MINIMUM DESIGN PARAMETERS
   FOR RESIDENTIAL STREETS
 
               Minimum Right Minimum Pavement
Street         Of Way Width  Surface Width    Maximum Gradient Minimum Gradient
Classification (Feet)        Including C/G    (Percent)        (Percent)
                             (Feet)
Alley          25            15               7                0.50
Land access/   50            31               7                0.40
local
Collector      60            31               5                0.40
Arterial       70            38               5                0.40
Pedestrianways 10            4                5                0.00
 
      3.   Horizontal Curves:
         a.   Where there is curvilinear horizontal alignment utilized for
subdivision streets, the minimum centerline radius to be used shall be as
indicated below:
 
Land access and local streets 150 feet
Collector street              300 feet
Arterial street               300 feet
 
         b.   If reserve curves are to be utilized, and the radii are less than
three hundred feet (300'), a tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long
should be introduced between the curves on collector streets and arterial
streets.
      4.   Vertical Curves: All grade changes shall be connected by vertical
curves. The length of vertical curves on major thoroughfares shall not be less
than thirty (30) times the algebraic difference in rates of grade, and not less
than fifteen (15) times the algebraic difference in rates of grade on all other
streets. The minimum length of vertical curves on all types of streets shall be
ten feet (10').
      5.   Topographical Considerations: Grades of streets shall conform as
closely as possible to the natural topography, but shall not exceed the maximum
grade nor be less than the minimum grade specified in table 5.1 of this
section. All streets shall be arranged so that as many as possible of the
potential building sites are at or above street grade.
      6.   Traffic Flow: Land access/local streets shall be laid out in such a
manner as to discourage use by through traffic. To effect a more desirable
street layout, the use of curvilinear streets, cul-de-sacs, or U-shaped streets
is encouraged. Rigid rectangular gridiron street patterns should be avoided for
land access and local streets.
      7.   Additional Width Of Existing Streets: Subdivisions that adjoin
existing streets shall dedicate additional right of way if necessary to meet
the minimum street width requirements set forth in this section as follows:
         a.   The entire additional right of way shall be provided where the
subdivision is on both sides of the existing street.
         b.   When the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing
street, one-half (1/2) or more of the required additional right of way shall be
provided as deemed necessary by the planning committee or village board.
      8.   Half Streets: Half streets shall be prohibited except where
essential to reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with other
requirements of this title and when the planning committee finds that it will
be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining
property is subdivided.
      9.   Private Streets And Reserve Strips: There shall be no private
streets platted in any subdivision. Every subdivided lot shall be served from a
dedicated street. There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to
streets, and there shall be no reserve strips or areas enabling access to
interior lots from streets in residential subdivisions.
      10.   Dead End Streets: Dead end streets shall be either temporary stub
streets or permanent cul-de-sac streets.
         a.   Temporary Stub Streets: Streets shall be so arranged as to
provide the continuation of collector streets between adjacent properties when
such continuation is consistent with good transportation planning and/or is
necessary for adequate traffic circulation, effective fire and police
protection, and efficient provision of utilities. If a street must dead end
temporarily because the adjacent property is undeveloped, the right of way
shall be extended to the property line, and no strip that would prevent
connections with future streets shall be reserved. A temporary all weather
surface turnabout with a minimum radius of thirty feet (30') shall be provided
at the terminus of any temporary dead end street that serves more than four (4)
lots.
         b.   Permanent Cul-De-Sac Streets: The terminus of a permanent cul-
de-sac street shall not be closer than one hundred feet (100') to the boundary
of an adjacent tract. A cul-de-sac turnaround, having a minimum right of way
radius of sixty feet (60') and a minimum pavement radius of fifty feet (50')
(measured to the back of curb and/or gutter) shall be provided at the end of
every permanent cul-de-sac street. Cul-de-sacs shall not be more than five
hundred feet (500') in length (measured from street of origin to end of right
of way) unless necessitated by some unusual conditions of topography.
      11.   Alleys: Alleys are not permitted in residential areas unless deemed
necessary by the planning committee.
      12.   Pedestrianways: Pedestrianways with a minimum width of ten feet
(10') may be provided to facilitate pedestrian movement in the neighborhood.
Such way is recommended in all blocks that are more than eight hundred feet
(800') long and for access to community facilities that do not have pedestrian
access from two (2) or more streets.
      13.   Street Names: Every proposed street which is obviously in alignment
with an existing named street shall be given the same name as the existing
street. The name assigned to any proposed street which is not in alignment with
an existing named street shall not duplicate nor be phonetically similar to the
name of any existing street regardless of any difference in designation such as
"Avenue", "Boulevard", "Drive", "Place", "Court", etc. (1984 Code § 6-8-3)
      14.   Street Numbers: Street numbers in any block of any proposed
subdivision shall correspond and conform with the numerical grid system set
forth in exhibit A attached to the ordinance codified herein which is hereby
adopted by the village for purposes of assigning address numbers to residences,
commercial buildings and other structures located within the village.
Residences, commercial buildings and other structures located along the north
and west sides of any street shall be odd numbered; residences, commercial
buildings and other structures located along the south and east sides of any
street shall be even numbered. Street signs placed at corners within any
subdivision shall bear, in addition to the requirements contained in subsection
11-5-4E of this chapter, a number indicating the corresponding location of the
particular block with respect to the grid system adopted in exhibit A attached
to the ordinance codified herein.
   C.   Intersections:
      1.   Not more than two (2) streets shall intersect at any one point.
Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right
angles. In no case shall two (2) streets intersect at an angle of less than
seventy degrees (70°). An oblique (less than 70 degrees) street shall be curved
approaching an intersection and shall be approximately at right angles with
said intersection for at least one hundred feet (100') therefrom, unless the
subdivider's engineer recommends, and the engineer for the village concurs,
that a lesser distance would be in accordance with safe and accepted traffic
engineering practices.
      2.   Proposed new intersections along one side of an existing street
shall, wherever practicable, coincide with any existing intersection on the
opposite side of such street. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than
one hundred twenty five feet (125') are prohibited unless the intersected
street has divided lanes without median breaks at either intersection.
      3.   Returns at intersections shall be made concentric and shall be
rounded by a radius of not less than twenty feet (20') at the right of way
line, and not less than thirty feet (30') at the back of curb line.
      4.   An area having no greater than a three percent (3%) slope for a
distance of seventy five feet (75') from the centerline of the intersection
should be provided for any approach to an intersection.
      5.   The cross slope on all streets, including intersections, should not
exceed three percent (3%).
      6.   Whenever any proposed intersection involves earth banks or existing
vegetation within fifty feet (50') of the intersection of curb lines, such
ground and/or vegetation shall be cut in conjunction with the grading of the
public right of way to the extent necessary to provide an adequate sight
distance 1 .
   D.   Easements: At locations within the subdivision where utilities and
drainage facilities are not to be constructed within public rights of way, the
subdivider shall make provision for easements for such installations.
Preliminary plats shall be submitted to the electric, gas, and telephone
companies for their input regarding easements.
      1.   Utility Easements: Utility easements, not less than twenty feet
(20') wide for sanitary sewers and not less than ten feet (10') wide for water
mains, gas, electric, telephone and cable TV, shall be provided where
necessary. Normally, in the case of abutting lots, an equal amount should be
taken from each lot. Property owners may (at their own risk) plant shrubbery or
hedges or install fences on the easement areas. Utilities (private and public),
however, in order to have access for repair, shall have the election to destroy
said improvements and restore the area only by grading and seeding or to have
alternate access through the owner's property.
      2.   Drainage Easements: Easements of adequate width for stormwater
drainage (surface or storm sewer) shall be provided as necessary for
satisfactory disposal of stormwater runoff. In no case shall such easements be
less than ten feet (10') in width. Easements for drainage retention shall be
provided as necessary.
      3.   Electric, Telephone, And Cable Television Lines: Electric,
telephone, and cable television (if any) service lines shall be installed
underground throughout every residential subdivision whenever feasible.
Underground service connections shall be provided at the property line of each
platted lot. All such conduits or cables shall be located within easements or
public rights of way in such a manner that they do not interfere with other
underground services/utilities. No underground utilities shall be constructed
until their physical location is approved in writing by the village board.
Utility companies shall submit the proposed layout of their facilities on paper
to the village for use in the approval process.
      4.   Ground Subject To Periodic Flooding: Where a subdivision is
traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be
provided a drainage easement conforming substantially with the lines of such
watercourse. It shall include an additional area, ten feet (10') wide,
adjoining both edges of the established area that would be affected by the 100-
year storm, as certified by the subdivider or his engineer.
   E.   Dedication/Reservation Of Right Of Way:
      1.   Dedicated Right Of Way Required:
         a.   The subdivider shall dedicate at least the minimum right of way
indicated in table 5.1 of this section whenever he proposes to build any of the
listed streets.
         b.   Whenever the subdivider proposes to build any of the listed
streets, he shall dedicate the right of way in excess of the stated minimum
where, in the professional opinion of the engineer for the village:
            (1)   Due to topography, additional width is necessary to provide
adequate sight lines; and
            (2)   Due to the location of streams, railroad tracks, etc.,
additional width is needed to construct bridges, underpasses, and/or safe
approaches thereto.
      2.   Reservation Of Right Of Way: The subdivider shall reserve the right
of way whenever the subdivision abuts an existing street that does not meet the
standards set forth in table 5.1 of this section. The subdivider shall reserve
sufficient right of way along the side of the street abutting the subdivision
so that, when additional right of way is acquired on the other side, it will be
possible to comply with said standards.
      3.   Right Of Way Part Of Minimum Setback: Any land that is dedicated or
reserved for public right of way shall not be counted in determining compliance
with the lot size and setback requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance.
   F.   Reservation Of Land For Public Purposes: When a school board, park
board, municipality, or the county has gone on record as desiring to purchase a
parcel(s) in a proposed subdivision for school, park, or other public purpose,
the owner or subdivider shall reserve said parcel(s) for acquisition of such
public entity for a period of twelve (12) months beginning on the date the
final plat is recorded. If, within this twelve (12) month period, an
acquisition price cannot be agreed upon or condemnation proceedings have not
been instituted, the owner or subdivider may sell, subdivide, or otherwise
dispose of said parcel(s). (1984 Code § 6-8-3)
   G.   Dedication Of Park Land Or Payment Of Fees In Lieu Thereof: As a
condition of approval of a preliminary plan of a subdivision or large scale
development, each subdivider or developer will be required to dedicate land for
park and recreational purposes to serve the immediate and future needs of the
residents of the development and village or to distribute cash in lieu of
actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the village,
in accordance with the following criteria and formula:
      1.   Criteria For Requiring Park And Recreation Land Dedication:
         a.   Requirement And Population Ratio: For purposes of this dedication
requirement, the developer shall dedicate to the village one thousand four
hundred fifty (1,450) square feet of real estate per dwelling unit in the
proposed development.
         b.   Credit For Private Open Spaces And Recreation Areas:
            (1)   Where private open space for park and recreational purposes
is provided in a proposed subdivision, and such space is to be owned and
maintained by the residents of that residential development, such areas shall
be credited against the requirements of dedication for park and recreation
purposes. In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks
will imply a substantial degree of improvement and the installation of
recreational facilities, including equipment, by the developer as part of his
obligation. When the private open space includes improvements and the
installation of recreation facilities, one-half (1/2) of the land area which
would be required for dedication under this title shall be sufficient for
credit for private open space.
            (2)   Detailed plans for private open space, including
specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the village,
and before any credit is given, the subdivider or developer must guarantee that
these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by
the execution of the appropriate legal documents. Private swimming clubs are
included in this provision.
            (3)   If the amount of private open space is less than the amount
required for credit for private open space, the remainder shall be made up in
land dedication or fees.
      2.   Determination Of Land Dedication Or Fees In Lieu Thereof: Whether
the board accepts land dedication or elects to require payment of a fee in lieu
thereof, or a combination, shall be determined by consideration of the
following:
         a.   Size and share of the residential development and land available
for dedication.
         b.   Topography, geology, access and location of land in the
subdivision.
         c.   The determination of the village board of trustees as to whether
land shall be dedicated or whether a fee shall be charged, or a combination
thereof, shall be final and conclusive.
      3.   Procedure:
         a.   Action Of Village: At the time of preliminary plan approval for
the subdivision, the board shall determine, as part of such approval, whether
to require a dedication of land within the subdivision, payment of a fee in
lieu thereof, a combination of both, or if private open space is adequate. If
land is to be dedicated, the preliminary plan of subdivision shall indicate
such dedications. If cash dedications are to be used in lieu of land
dedications, the amount of cash dedications and the computations that resulted
in determining said amount shall be submitted in writing by the developer at
the time the preliminary plan of subdivision is filed. It shall be the
responsibility of the planning committee to make recommendations to the village
board regarding the adequacy of the proposed land dedication or cash donation
in lieu of land dedication.
         b.   Prerequisites For Approval Of Final Plat: Where dedication is
required, it shall be accomplished in accordance with the provisions of
Illinois Compiled Statutes. Where fees are required, the same shall be
deposited with the village clerk prior to board approval of the final plat of
subdivision. Open space covenants for private park or recreational facilities
shall be submitted to the village prior to final approval and shall be recorded
contemporaneously with the final plat.
         c.   Determination Of Amount Of Fees: The cash contributions in lieu
of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land in the
residential development under consideration that otherwise would have been
dedicated as a park.
         d.   Determination Of Fair Market Value: Fair market value shall be
determined as of the time of filing the final plat of subdivision in accordance
with the following:
            (1)   The fair market value as determined by the village board
based upon current appraisals; or
            (2)   If the subdivider or developer objects to such amount of
evaluation, he may, at his expense, obtain an appraisal of the property by a
qualified real estate appraiser approved by the village, which appraisal may be
accepted by the village board of trustees if found reasonable; or
            (3)   The village and subdivider may agree as to the fair market
value.
      4.   Uses Of Fees In Lieu:
         a.   Parks: Cash contributions in lieu of park and recreation land
dedication shall be held in trust by the village, or other public body
designated by the village, solely for the acquisition of park and recreation
land which will be available to serve immediate or future needs of the
residents of that subdivision or development, or for the improvement of the
existing local park and recreation land which already serves such needs.
         b.   Refunded Fees In Lieu: If any portion of a cash contribution is
not expended within fifteen (15) years from the date of receipt, it shall be
refunded to the developer who made such contribution. (1984 Code § 6-8-3)
   H.   Off Site Improvements: As a condition of approval of any preliminary or
final plat of subdivision, the village, at its discretion, may require any off
site improvements to adjacent streets, feeder streets, street curbs, water
mains, sanitary sewers, drains or other facilities for sewers and drains,
roadways, traffic signals or similar improvements as permitted by the laws of
the state, as amended from time to time. In addition, the village may enter
into an agreement with the developer or developers for the construction of off
site improvements and the apportionment of the cost of said off site
improvements between the developer's property and other properties benefited by
the improvements, and may agree to collect the proportionate share of such
costs for off site improvements from the developer or developers of other
properties benefited by the improvements as permitted by the statutes or the
laws of the state, as amended from time to time. (Ord. 1990-1, 2-6-1990; amd.
Ord. 1990-12, 6-5-1990; Ord. 1994-11, 5-3-1994; amd. 2010 Code; Ord. 2017-4, 3-
21-2017)

  10-7-4 of this code.
11-5-4: STREET AND ALLEY IMPROVEMENTS:
All streets and alleys shall be improved solely at the expense of the
subdivider in accordance with the requirements set forth herein. Typical
roadway and pavement sections are shown in subsection
11-5-9A of this chapter. Unless stated otherwise in this title, all
construction shall be performed in accordance with state standard
specifications for road and bridge construction adopted October 1, 1983, or the
latest revised edition adopted by the Illinois department of transportation.
   A.   Pavement Structure: All streets and alleys shall be paved across the
entire surface width specified in table 5.1 of this chapter. The structural
composition of the pavement shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth
in table 5.2 below. Design requirements for both rigid and flexible pavements
are set forth hereinafter. Should the engineer for the village or the
developer's engineer determine that the minimal standards are not adequate for
a given condition (i.e., traffic volume, size of loads, subgrade support,
drainage, etc.), the required pavement thickness will be designed in accordance
with the latest edition or revision thereof of the design manual of the state
department of transportation bureau of design.

Abbreviations:

Maximum lift thickness:

BAM = 6 inches
1-11 Binder = 21/2 inches
1-11 Surface = 2 inches
      1.   Flexible Pavements: Flexible pavements are to be constructed as
multilayered structures combining hot mix bituminous concrete/bituminous base/
crushed stone base/subbase. Each layer of material is to be constructed in
lifts not to exceed the maximum lift thickness (compacted) specified in table
5.2 of this section. The minimum width of any single pass for any lift/layer of
bituminous mixture shall be ten feet (10'). There are alternate designs for
either deep strength asphalt or bituminous concrete on a crushed stone base/
subbase.
      2.   Rigid Pavements: Rigid pavements are specified as either reinforced
or unreinforced Portland cement concrete to be constructed either on the earth
subgrade or on a crushed stone subbase or underlayment. Alternate designs are
shown for two (2) of the seven (7) street classifications. The underlayment is
to be one-fourth inch (1/4") thick fabric such as "Bidim" or "Petromat", or
equal.
         a.   Contraction Joints:
            (1)   Contraction joints are to be provided at the spacings shown
in table 5.2 of this section for each of the various alternates. These
transverse joints are to be sawed joints that are one- eighth inch (1/8") to
one-fourth inch (1/4") wide with a depth equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the
pavement thickness. Sawed contraction joints are to be sawed within twenty four
(24) hours of placement of the concrete. All contraction joints are to be
dowelled with the exception of alleys and land access residential streets.
Dowel sizes and spacing shall comply with the following requirements:
 
Pavement  Minimum Dowel Diameter Minimum Dowel Length Minimum Dowel Spacing
Thickness
6"        5/8"                   12"                  12"
7"        3/4"                   15"                  15"
8"        1"                     15"                  12"
 
            (2)   The dowel units are to be smooth, plain round bars placed at
mid height of the pavement with an expansion cap at one end. The bars, or
assemblies, shall be placed so that the bars are parallel to the centerline and
to the pavement surface and shall be treated to prevent bonding with the
concrete.
         b.   Longitudinal Joints:
            (1)   Longitudinal joints shall be constructed no closer than eight
feet (8') and no farther apart than fifteen feet (15'). The longitudinal joints
may be either "construction" joints or "sawed" joints. In either case, there
shall be transverse no. 4 deformed tie bars, thirty inches (30") long, spaced
at thirty inch (30") centers along all longitudinal joints. This includes the
joint between the pavement and curb/gutter if the curb/gutter is not
constructed integral with the pavement. As an option to tie bars, either a half
round or trapezoidal preformed keyway meeting the following dimensions may be
used on longitudinal joints, excluding the gutter joint:
 
Pavement Thickness Half Round Diameter Edge Height Trapezoidal
                                                   Depth Inside Height
6"                 2"                  2"          1"    11/4"
7"                 2"                  21/4"       1"    11/4"
8"                 21/2"               21/4"       1"    11/4"
 
            (2)   Sawed longitudinal joints shall be sawed within ten (10) days
of concrete placement and prior to any traffic or vehicles traveling on the
surface.
         c.   Transverse Construction Joints: Transverse construction joints
shall be constructed at the end of each day's run or at locations where a
"cold" joint will occur due to a delay or interruption in placement operations.
All transverse construction joints shall be "tied" with no. 4 deformed bars,
thirty six inches (36") long, spaced at twelve inch (12") centers. Construction
joints must be at least five feet (5') from a contraction joint.
         d.   Pavement Reinforcement: Pavement reinforcement shall be used in
all rigid pavements designated as SRPCC in table 5.2 of this section.
Reinforcement shall be welded wire fabric six inches by twelve inches (6" x
12") with W 4 wire transversely and W 5.5 wire longitudinally weighing
approximately fifty four (54) pounds per one hundred (100) square feet. The
fabric shall be lapped twelve inches (12") on transverse laps and six inches
(6") on longitudinal laps. Reinforcement shall be placed on the subgrade and
supported by proper chairs and spacers, prior to paving, at the heights
specified below:
 
Pavement Thickness Depth Below Pavement Surface
   6"           2" minimum; 3" maximum
   7"           21/2" minimum; 31/2" maximum
   8"           3" minimum; 4" maximum
 
   B.   Curb And Gutter:
      1.   All streets, except alleys, shall be constructed with Portland
cement concrete combination curb and gutter and/or V-type gutter in accordance
with the dimensions and specifications shown therefor in subsection
11-5-9A of this chapter. Either combination curb and gutter or V-type gutter,
at the developer's option, may be used on land access, local, and collector
streets. Only combination curb and gutter shall be used on arterial streets.
      2.   Curb and/or gutter may be constructed either integrally or
separately in conjunction with Portland cement concrete pavement. If
constructed separately, the gutter flag shall be "tied" to PCC pavement with
thirty inch (30") long no. 4 reinforcing bars spaced at thirty inch (30")
centers.
   C.   Unpaved Areas: All unpaved areas within the dedicated street area shall
be graded and seeded in an approved manner.
   D.   Curb Radii: All curb corners shall have a minimum radius of not less
than thirty feet (30').
   E.   Street Name Signs: A four-way metal street sign shall be installed at
each street intersection. Signs shall be flat, reflectorized, and yellow with
black letters. The letters shall be at least three and one-half inches (31/2")
high. Numerals shall be used for numbered streets. The post shall be not less
than two inches (2") inside diameter galvanized iron, or equal, ten feet (10')
long. They shall be installed at a height not less than seven feet (7'), and
shall be placed not less than one foot (1') nor more than ten feet (10') from
the edge of the pavement.
   F.   Sidewalks: Sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of each street
and they shall conform to the requirements specified herein:
      1.   Dimensions:
   Width = Four feet (4') (minimum)
   Thickness = Four feet (4') (minimum)
      2.   Location (at village board discretion):
         a.   One foot (1') in from the property line.
      3.   Grade: Parallel with the street grade.
      4.   Materials: Concrete.
      5.   Contraction joints: With joint tool at five foot (5') centers.
      6.   Expansion joints: One-half inch (1/2") premolded joint filler where
abutting back of curb/gutter. (1984 Code § 6-8-4)
   G.   Streetlights: The developer shall comply with the following policy
concerning street lighting in any subdivision proposed for approval by the
village:
      1.   Lights using two hundred (200) watt high pressure sodium bulbs shall
be provided at every intersection.
      2.   Lights using one hundred fifty (150) watt high pressure sodium bulbs
shall be provided at every other lot line on alternating sides of the street.
      3.   The location of the lights shall be shown on the construction plans
reviewed and approved by the engineer for the village.
      4.   If the developer uses lights provided by CILCO or Menard Electric,
they shall use their decorative poles. Any additional costs for decorative
poles shall be paid by the developer.
      5.   If the developer chooses to supply his own decorative lighting on
decorative poles, the following standards shall apply:
         a.   Mounting height of the luminaires from the base of poles to
center of bulb shall be sixteen feet (16'), plus or minus, depending on the
design of the luminaires. Poles shall be designed for eighty (80) miles per
hour wind loading.
         b.   Acorn type polycarbonate or polyacryl luminaires shall be used.
         c.   A type III lighting pattern shall be provided as defined in the
American national standard practice for roadway lighting (RP-8), appendix E,
section E3.2.3.
      6.   If the developer chooses to use decorative lighting on decorative
poles, the developer shall provide catalog cuts on the proposed lighting
equipment to the engineer for the village for approval before any equipment is
ordered.
      7.   a. The developer is responsible for maintenance of streetlights and
poles for one year after the subdivision plat is accepted by the village.
         b.   The village, in conjunction with the utility (CILCO or Menard
Electric), will maintain all streetlights, including decorative lights, after
the expiration of the one year period from acceptance by the village.
      8.   Streetlights shall be installed and operative within sixty (60) days
of the time the curbs are completed or the electrical service lines are
installed, whichever occurs last.
   H.   Addresses: Upon completion of construction of streets and curbs in any
subdivision within the village, where construction is completed after the
effective date hereof, the developer shall paint yellow numerals at least three
and one-half inches (31/2") in height on a six inch by twelve inch (6" x 12")
black background at the center of each lot on the surface of the curb or gutter
fronting each lot, indicating the street address or addresses established under
the provisions of this title.
   I.   Direct Burial Light Pole Foundations: Where direct burial light pole
foundations are used, the following standards shall apply:
      1.   The embedment depth of the pole shall be in accordance with the
manufacturer's recommendations, but shall not be less than five feet (5').
      2.   The diameter of the embedment hole shall be in accordance with the
pole manufacturer's recommendations, but shall not be less than two feet (2')
larger in diameter than the buried portion of the pole.
      3.   The butt end of the pole shall be placed in the embedment hole and
as a minimum, the bottom two feet (2') of the hole shall be filled with
concrete. The remainder of the hole shall be filled with compacted earth
backfill. (Ord. 1990-5, 4-3-1990; amd. Ord. 2002-7, 3-19-2002; Ord. 2010-6, 5-
4-2010; Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-5-5: DRAINAGE AND STORM SEWERS:
Every residential subdivision shall be provided with drainage facilities which
can satisfactorily accommodate the stormwater surface runoff incident to the
10-year design storm. The drainage facilities in any commercial or industrial
subdivision shall be designed to handle stormwater runoff from the 15-year
design storm. These minimal design requirements shall not be construed to
relieve the subdivider of any legal responsibilities for downstream/upstream
stormwater damages inflicted by runoff or backup from the development.
   A.   General Design Considerations: The plans and specifications shall
include provisions to show compliance with the drainage laws of the state and
any subdivision thereof in effect at that time. By requiring that the
subdivider evidence compliance with drainage law(s), the village assumes no
responsibility to landowners or others for damage caused by noncompliance with
such law(s).
      1.   Storm Sewers: Properly sized storm sewers shall be provided to carry
surface runoff from streets and curb and/or gutters. Such storm sewers shall be
of sufficient length that they shall transport the runoff to rear lot lines or
existing natural drainageways or swales, provided their location does not
encroach upon the building site.
      2.   Drainage Swales: Natural drainage swales may be utilized to
accommodate surface runoff, provided they are located near lot lines and the
flows induced therein do not pose health or safety hazards for residents.
      3.   Accommodation Of Upstream Drainage Areas: Drainage facilities shall
be adequate to accommodate potential runoff from the entire drainage area
upstream of the proposed subdivision. Potential runoff shall be determined on
the basis of maximum land use of the upstream area that is consistent with
current zoning or adjacent land use trends.
      4.   Drainage Detention: In order to protect downstream property from
potential damages by increased flows or greater velocities, it may be necessary
for the subdivider to provide for drainage detention facilities. The village
reserves the right to require such installations where it is deemed necessary
in the interest of public safety and welfare. Drainage detention facilities
should be designed so that the post-development release rate does not exceed
the pre-development conditions for the 10-year and 100-year design storm.
      5.   Discharge From Groundwater Sumps 1 : All lots on which proposed
buildings will require the use of groundwater sumps to protect foundations and
floors from leaking must be provided with underground storm sewers designed to
carry the sump pump discharge to the street storm sewer system or surface
drainage easements. In no case will groundwater sump discharge be allowed to
drain either directly or indirectly onto village streets.
   B.   Technical Requirements: Storm drainage facilities shall be designed and
constructed in accordance with the criteria set forth and the standards
contained in subsection
11-5-9B of this chapter.
      1.   Pipe/Storm Sewers: All pipe sewers shall be determined by
utilization of either the rational method, or the SCS method, or both, for the
design storm(s) previously specified.
         a.   The minimum diameter permitted shall be twelve inches (12")
except as indicated in subsection B1d of this section.
         b.   Pipes/storm sewers located under paved surfaces shall be
reinforced concrete pipe with rubber gasket joints and sufficient wall
thickness and reinforcement to carry the intended loading with the materials
meeting the requirements of ASTM C-76 and ASTM C-443.
         c.   Pipes/storm sewers located outside paved surfaces and under
nominal fill loading may be of any of the following materials:
            (1)   Plastic truss pipe meeting the requirements of ASTM D-2680.
            (2)   Corrugated aluminum pipe meeting the requirements of AASHTO
M-196, minimum plate thickness of 14-gauge for D = 12 inches to 27 inches; 12-
gauge for D = 30 inches and up.
            (3)   Reinforced concrete pipe with sufficient wall thickness and
reinforcement to carry the intended loading and meeting the requirements of
ASTM C-76.
            (4)   Bituminous coated corrugated galvanized steel pipe meeting
the requirements of AASHTO M-36 and M-190, minimum plate thickness of 16-gauge
for D = 12 inches to 21 inches; 14-gauge for D = 24 inches and up.
            (5)   Pipe types not listed shall be approved in writing by the
engineer for the village before use.
            (6)   The subdivider shall be responsible for increasing minimum
plate gauges as the final loading dictates.
         d.   For sump pump drainage only, four inch (4") corrugated plastic
drainage pipe may be used, provided design calculations indicate adequate
capacity. In addition, a four inch (4") cleanout meeting the approval of the
engineer for the village shall be provided at the intersection of the sump
discharge pipe and the four inch (4") drain pipe.
         e.   Installation shall be in accordance with "good practice". All
trenches for pipes/storm sewers that are located under paved surfaces and all
trenches outside of the subgrade where the inner edge of the trench is closer
than two feet (2') to the edge of the proposed pavement shall be properly
backfilled with fine aggregate, one hundred percent (100%) of which shall pass
the three-eighths inch (3/8") sieve.
      2.   Inlets/Catch Basins: The spacings for inlets/catch basins shall be
calculated such that the runoff from the design storm shall not encroach upon
the pavement by more than six feet (6'). Under no circumstances shall the
spacing exceed four hundred feet (400'). Inlets/catch basins shall be
constructed in accordance with the standards in subsection
11-5-9B of this chapter.
      3.   Drainage Grades: Minimum/maximum gradients of pipes/storm sewers and
earth drainageways/swales shall conform to the following criteria:
         a.   Pipes/storm sewers:
 
Minimum grade = 0.3%
Maximum grade = None; riprap and/or energy dissipators shall be utilized as
                needed at discharge points to minimize erosion
 
         b.   Earth drainage/swales:
 
Minimum grade = 0.5% - may reduce to 0.35% if they are paved with concrete
Maximum grade = 3.0% with no protection other than sod
              12.0% with paving, riprap and/or energy dissipators, etc.
 
      4.   Manholes: Manholes conforming to the requirements set forth in
subsection
11-5-9B of this chapter shall be installed to all changes in vertical grade or
horizontal alignment of storm sewers if at locations other than inlets/catch
basins. (Ord. 2001-35, 12-4-2001; amd. Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)

1 1. See also section
  8-3-8 of this code.
11-5-6: GRADING AND CLEARING:
Grading and clearing necessitated by the construction of roadway and drainage
facilities shall be done in such a manner as to assure uniform subgrade support
with adequate bearing capacity to properly support the loading/structures to be
superimposed. In order to help achieve this result, the subdivider shall comply
with the following requirements:
   A.   Clearing And Grubbing: Prior to grading within the limits of the right
of way, the entire area to be affected with improvements (i.e., pavement,
water, sewer, drainage, etc.) shall be cleared of all tree stumps, roots,
brush, and other objectional materials and of all trees not intended for
preservation.
   B.   Embankments: Embankments to be constructed within the roadway right of
way by the subdivider shall be done in a manner compatible with good road
construction practices and in accordance with the following provisions:
      1.   Construction: Fills shall be constructed in lifts not to exceed
twelve inches (12") loose. No wood, trash, or other objectionable material
shall be placed in fills.
      2.   Compaction: Each lift shall be properly compacted to a density not
less than ninety percent (90%) of the maximum standard lab density as
determined by AASHTO T-99. The upper six inches (6") of embankment shall be
compacted to a minimum of ninety five percent (95%) of maximum standard lab
density. Large clods and excessively wet fill material shall be disked and/or
aerated as required to achieve the minimum required density and result in a
stable embankment. Compaction shall be achieved with a roller capable of
properly compacting the given type of embankment material. In the case of fine
grained soils, a sheepsfoot roller shall be deemed suitable.
      3.   Compaction Tests: The village may require the subdivider to furnish,
at his expense, results of field compaction tests for verification of proper
construction. Such tests shall be performed and certified by a respectable
testing lab or engineering firm.
   C.   Subgrades: In areas where embankment is to be placed, the material
shall be properly compacted up to subgrade elevation. In the case of cut
sections, the subgrade shall be cleared of all unsuitable material, including,
but not limited to, vegetation; tree stumps and roots; trash; debris; soft,
spongy soil; etc., for a minimum depth of eighteen inches (18") below subgrade
elevation. The upper six inches (6") of the entire length of subgrade (cut or
fill) shall be compacted to at least ninety five percent (95%) of maximum
standard lab density.
   D.   Erosion Control: The design of every subdivision shall be consistent
with the natural limitations presented by topography and soil so as to create
the least potential for soil erosion. Soil shall be exposed during construction
for the shortest feasible period of time.
      1.   Temporary Erosion Control: The subdivider shall be required to
install temporary erosion measures to prevent siltation of adjacent streams,
roads, private property, etc.
      2.   Permanent Installation:
         a.   The subdivider shall be required to incorporate the appropriate
permanent devices to prevent long term erosion and siltation. Such
installations may include sediment basins, desilting basins, riprap, energy
dissipators, etc.
         b.   All development and improvements to be made within any
subdivision shall be subject to any village ordinance(s), county regulations,
or state laws relative to soil erosion and sediment control, insofar as they
are applicable.
   E.   Vegetation Preservation: Existing vegetation, especially trees having a
diameter of four inches (4") or more when measured at a point twelve inches
(12") above the ground, should be retained and protected to the maximum extent
consistent with development of the site. (1984 Code § 6-8-6)
11-5-7: WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM:
   A.   It is the responsibility of the subdivider to install, or have
installed, the necessary water mains to serve his subdivision. Prior to actual
field installation of said facilities, it shall be necessary for the
subdivider's engineer to prepare detailed construction plans, determine a
complete bill of materials, and complete the necessary papers for the
environmental protection agency permit in accordance with the appropriate
requirements of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the Village of
Williamsville. All plans shall be approved by the Village of Williamsville
prior to the planning committee’s final approval and submittal to the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency. All design and construction shall be in
accordance with the applicable portions of the current edition of the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois" unless
otherwise directed by the Village of Williamsville.
   B.   Final Acceptance: Occupancy permits for new dwelling units served by
extended water mains will not be issued until the Williamsville water
department has accepted maintenance responsibility for the newly constructed
water mains. (1984 Code § 6-8-7; amd. Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-5-8: SANITARY SEWER FACILITIES:
It is the sole responsibility of the subdivider to provide a sewage disposal
system complying with the regulations of the Illinois department of public
health (private sewage disposal licensing act and code 1 ), the Illinois
environmental protection agency, and the operator of the public sewer system to
be expanded. If the public sanitary sewer system is within seven hundred fifty
feet (750') of the proposed subdivision 2 , and said system has the available
capacity, the subdivider shall extend the existing system and sewer his entire
proposed development at his own expense.
   A.   Extension Of Existing Mains:
      1.   Plans Required: Whenever the existing public sanitary sewer system
is to be extended for a proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall have
detailed construction plans prepared by a professional engineer registered in
the state of Illinois. The plans and necessary permit application papers
required by the Illinois environmental protection agency shall be submitted to
the village for approval by the engineer for the village and the chair of the
planning committee.
      2.   Scope Of Extension: The subdivider shall extend the sanitary sewer
system throughout the subdivision in such a manner as to service every lot. No
lot may remain unserved unless such exemption is made in writing by the village
clerk and specifically referenced by subdivision lot number.
      3.   Construction Requirements: The subdivider shall install a four inch
(4") service tap for each lot to be served with sufficient four inch (4")
service line to place the service a minimum of five feet (5') beyond the lot
lines of each lot. All design and construction shall be in accordance with the
applicable requirements of the current edition of the "Standard Specifications
For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois". All principal sanitary
sewer lines shall be located within the street right of way or public easement.
      4.   Inspection: Subsequent to completion of construction, the subdivider
and/or contractor shall provide a television inspection of the installed main.
      5.   Maintenance: The subdivider shall be responsible for all maintenance
of the sewer main, manholes, lift station(s), and service connections until
such time as the engineer for the village accepts the paving and the grading
adjacent to the sewer as complete and accepted by the village.
      6.   Warranty: The subdivider shall be responsible for a one year period
after the village has received notice of beginning of operation of a sanitary
sewer system for all defective mains, manholes, lift stations, sewer taps,
backfill settlement, etc.
   B.   Alternate Methods Of Disposal:
      1.   In the event it is not possible or feasible for the subdivider to
extend the public sewer system into the proposed subdivision, for whatever
reason, the subdivider has the right to petition the village to install an
alternative method of sewage disposal. Any such petition shall be considered on
an individual basis with each case standing on its own merit. No subdivision
shall be approved without the village approval of the method of sewage
disposal.
      2.   Upon written approval of the village board, the subdivider may
install individual sewage disposal systems, provided the lot size is in excess
of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. If such installations are permitted,
they shall be designed and installed in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the requirements and regulations of the private sewage disposal
licensing act 1 and code of the Illinois department of public health. (1984
Code § 6-8-8; amd. Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)

  8-3-2D of this code and subsection 11-3C-3G1 of this title.

11-6-7:    Recording The Minor Subdivision Plat
11-6-8:    Limitations On Minor Subdivisions
11-6-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   A minor subdivision is the creation of a total of up to four (4) lots
(counting the remainder of the original tract from which the lots are created)
which front along a public road from which access is permitted.
   B.   The minor subdivision is designed to allow an abbreviated approval
process. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-2: LOCATION MAP:
   A.   Location Map Submission Requirements: The location map shall consist of
data added to an existing base map of a suitable scale, covering an area of at
least one mile radius from the tract proposed for development. The location map
shall show the following information:
      1.   Title of proposed subdivision.
      2.   North point, scale and date.
      3.   Names, addresses and phone numbers of the owner, subdivider,
engineer and registered land surveyor with the name, address and phone number
of the contact person to whom any notice is to be sent.
      4.   Outline of the entire area owned or controlled by the subdivider
with approximate boundary dimensions and total acreage.
      5.   General land legal description of the area.
      6.   Existing streets and roads expected to serve the area to be
subdivided.
      7.   Existing utility lines expected to serve the area to be subdivided.
      8.   Existing and proposed zoning.
      9.   Method of sewage disposal.
      10.   Method of water supply.
      11.   Electric service provider.
      12.   Fire protection district.
      13.   School district.
      14.   Soils analysis if private sewage systems are proposed.
      15.   Test well data.
      16.   Plan to upgrade adjacent roads if applicable.
      17.   Sketch of proposed lot layout.
      18.   Location of the one hundred (100) year floodplain.
      19.   Location of any outstanding natural features.
   B.   Location Map Review Process:
      1. The subdivider shall submit nineteen (19) prints of the location map
to the Village Clerk. Subdivision documents must be submitted seven (7)
calendar days prior to a regularly scheduled planning commission meeting to be
considered by the commission at that meeting.
      2.   The Village Clerk shall retain one print and distribute the
remaining prints as follows:
         a.   Seven (7) prints to the Planning Committee;
         b.   One print to the Zoning Administrator;
         c.   One print to the Village Engineer;
         d.   One print to the fire protection district;
         e.   One print to the Village of Williamsville Water Department;
         f.   One print to the Sangamon County Water Reclamation District;
         g.   One print to the Township Highway Commissioner; if applicable;
         h.   One print to the Sangamon County Superintendent, if applicable;
         i.   One print to the Sangamon County Soil and Water Conservation
District;
         j.   One print to the appropriate school district; and
         k.   Two (2) prints to be retained by the planning commission for
transmittal to effected utilities or agencies serving the area to be
subdivided.
      3.   The entities listed in subsection (B)(2) shall transmit their
comments on suitability of the site in writing to the planning commission staff
within one week of receipt.
      4.   The planning commission shall review the suitability of the site
based on comments received and the suitability criteria outlined in
11-2-4 . The planning commission shall either approve or disapprove the
location map based on the suitability of the site at its next regularly
scheduled meeting after the plan was filed. If the location map is disapproved,
the owners shall be informed in writing of the noncompliance found.
      5.   A location map shall be valid for a period of one year after
approval. If a final plat has not been submitted within the one year period,
approval of the location map shall expire. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-3: FINAL PLAT SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Final Plat Submission Requirements: The final plat shall be consistent
with the current zoning district classification of the property. The following
shall be submitted on a plan drawn to a scale of not more than one hundred feet
(100') to the inch or in accompanying documents:
      1.   North point, scale, and date of preparation and any revisions.
      2.   Names and addresses of the owner, engineer and registered land
surveyor.
      3.   Total acreage.
      4.   Lot numbers.
      5.   Existing utilities and drainage courses within and adjacent to the
site.
      6.   Location of all present property lines, section lines, streets,
buildings and watercourses within the area and within one hundred feet (100')
of the area.
      7.   Location of proposed lots, setback lines and utility easements.
      8.   Contours referring to the United States Geological Survey datum with
intervals of two feet (2') or less unless a greater interval is required
because of terrain.
      9.   If applicable, a note on the final plat stating: "Approval of this
final plat by the Village of Sherman does not constitute a guarantee that well
water is of adequate quantity or quality for residential needs or that a
suitable sewage disposal system can be constructed on each lot." Any guarantees
are the subdivider's responsibility.
      10.   Elevation and location of floodplain with location of required
monuments.
      11.   A statement indicating whether or not any part of the plat is
located in a special flood hazard area as identified by the Federal Emergency
Management Agency.
      12.   A notation stating any setback required through covenants if the
different from those of the appropriate zoning district.
      13.   Percolation test results, if necessary.
      14.   Seal and signature of Illinois Professional Land Surveyor with
appropriate statement that the plat meets the standards of practice of the
Illinois Professional Land Surveyors Act.
      15.   A list of requested variances, if any.
   B.   Accompanying Documents: The following documents shall accompany the
final plat:
      1.   Exhibit showing the location of wells and seepage field areas on
each lot.
      2.   Any covenants or restrictions relating to the requirements of this
title.
      3.   Exhibits showing half of an acres private sewage disposal system
area.
      4.   Exhibit showing areas restricted from private sewage disposal system
use. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-4: REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   The subdivider shall submit fifteen (15) prints of the final plat of
the minor subdivision to the Village Clerk accompanied by any requested
variances and a receipt for the filing fee. The subdivision documents must be
submitted seven (7) calendar days prior to a regularly scheduled Planning
Commission Meeting to be considered by the Commission at that meeting.
   B.   The Village Clerk shall retain one print and distribute the remaining
prints as follows:
      1.   Seven (7) prints to the Planning Committee;
      2.   One print to the Zoning Administrator;
      3.   One print to the Village Engineer;
      4.   One print to the Village of Williamsville Water Department;
      5.   One print to the fire protection district;
      6.   One print to the Sangamon County Water Reclamation District;
      7.   One print to the Township Highway Commissioner; if applicable; and
      8.   One print to the Sangamon County Superintendent, if applicable.
   C.   The reviewing entities shall transmit any comments or requirements to
the Planning Commission within seven (7) calendar days of receipt.
   D.   The Planning Commission shall recommend approval or disapproval no
later than its second regularly scheduled meeting after the plan was filed with
Village Clerk. Failure to act by the end of said second regularly scheduled
meeting shall constitute a recommendation of disapproval.
      1.   Disapproval: If the Planning Commission finds that the minor
subdivision plat does not meet the requirements of this chapter, it shall
specify its disapproval in writing and state the noncompliance found.
      2.   Approval: If the Planning Commission finds that the minor
subdivision plat meets the requirements of this chapter, the subdivider shall
submit the original and three (3) prints to the Planning Commission. The
following shall be printed or stamped on the original plat and prints and
signed by the Chairman of the Planning Commission:
   The Plat of this subdivision is recommended to the Village Board for
approval by the Sherman Planning Commission subject to the certifications set
forth in
11-6-5 .
   By:                                                          
   Chairman
   Dated:                                                     
   Sherman Planning Commission
   E.   The Planning Commission shall transmit the endorsed original plat and
two (2) prints to the Zoning Administrator for immediate reference to the
Village Board. One print of the endorsed minor subdivision plat shall remain on
file in the Planning Commission office. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-5: SUBMISSION OF MINOR SUBDIVISION PLAT TO THE VILLAGE BOARD:
   A.   Certificates: The following documents shall be submitted to the
Planning Commission before a final plat is transmitted to the Village Clerk.
      1.   A certificate provided by the subdivider from the Sangamon County
Clerk indicating that payment of taxes is not delinquent.
      2.   A signed statement of a registered professional engineer and the
owner of the land, or his duly authorized attorney, as required by state
statutes concerning drainage.
      3.   Notarized acknowledgment of the plat by the owner or a duly
authorized attorney. This item may be a separate document or on the plat
itself.
      4.   The certificate of an Illinois Professional Land Surveyor attesting
to the accuracy of the survey and the location of all monuments shown. The
certificate may be filed as a supplement to the final plat.
      5.   Notarized statement by owner indicating the school district(s) in
which the subdivision is located.
      6.   Executed covenants, if required.
   B.   If the requirements of this section have not been met within two (2)
years from Planning Commission approval, the existing approvals and
recommendations shall expire and a new location map shall be submitted if the
subdivider wishes to continue. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-6: VILLAGE BOARD APPROVAL:
When the requirements of
11-6-5 have been met, the Village Board may by resolution approve the minor
subdivision plat and authorize the Mayor to sign the plat for and in the name
of the Village of Sherman with the Village Clerk attesting to it. The Village
Clerk shall retain one print on file. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-7: RECORDING THE MINOR SUBDIVISION PLAT:
   A.   When the minor subdivision plat has been approved by the Village Board
and signed by the Mayor and Village Clerk, the original shall be recorded in
the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Sangamon County, Illinois by the
subdivider. The subdivider will deliver a copy of the recorded final plat
(containing the document number assigned by the county) to the village.
   B.   If the minor subdivision plat is not recorded within two (2) years
after approval by the Village Board, the plat must be resubmitted to the
Planning Commission to determine if any changes in the plat are needed to meet
the requirements of this title. No title to any lots shall be conveyed until
the original is recorded. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-6-8: LIMITATIONS ON MINOR SUBDIVISIONS:
Only one minor subdivision shall be allowed for any parcel of record. If four
(4) lots have been created from a parcel of record after May 8, 2001, all
additional divisions at a later time shall follow conventional subdivision
procedures. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
CHAPTER 7
TRACT SURVEY
SECTION:
11-7-1:    Purpose
11-7-2:    Submission Requirements
11-7-3:    Review Process
11-7-4:    Recording The Tract Survey
11-7-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   Tract survey approval shall be required as set forth in
11-1-3-1 .
   B.   Tract survey approval is designed to ensure that all divisions of land
comply with the State Plats Act, right-of-way and lot area and lot
configuration requirements of this title, and the appropriate zoning
ordinances. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-7-2: SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS:
When a tract survey is required by this title, the following shall be
submitted:
   A.   North arrow, scale and date.
   B.   Name, address and phone number of the land surveyor and owner.
   C.   Land survey showing right-of-way dedication in fee simple in
conformance with the Arterial Roadway Network Plan.
   D.   A certificate provided by the subdivider from the Sangamon County Clerk
indicating that payment of taxes is not delinquent.
   E.   Certification by an Illinois Professional Land Surveyor, together with
the surveyor's seal, attesting to the accuracy of the survey.
   F.   Owner's written acknowledgment of the survey and right-of-way or
easement dedication in fee simple on the final plat.
   G.   Statement indicating whether or not any part of the land surveyed is
located in a Special Flood Hazard Area.
   H.   Location of one hundred (100) year floodplain, if applicable.
   I.   Location of all buildings and their distances from front, rear and side
property lines.
   J.   Parcel identification number. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
11-7-3: REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   One original and four (4) copies of the tract survey shall be submitted
to the Plat Officer accompanied by the appropriate fee.
   B.   The Plat Officer shall review the survey to ensure that it conforms to
the pertinent requirements of this title and Title 10. The owner shall be
notified of tract survey approval or disapproval within seven (7) working days.
      1.   Disapproval: If the Plat Officer finds that the tract survey does
not meet the requirements of this code, the disapproval and noncompliance found
shall be specified in writing.
      2.   Approval: If the Plat Officer finds that the tract survey does meet
the requirements of this code, the following shall be printed or stamped on the
original and prints and signed by the Plat Officer:
County of Sangamon )
               )ss
State of Illinois       )
I, the Village of Sherman Plat officer, do hereby approve this tract survey in
accordance with the provisions of this section and in accordance with the
provisions of the Subdivision Regulations of the Village of Sherman, Illinois,
this             day of                        , 20          .
                                                         
Village of Sherman Plat Officer
   C.   The Plats Officer shall keep one copy and return the original and three
(3) copies of the approved tract survey to the owner for recording. (Ord. 2017-
4, 3-21-2017)
11-7-4: RECORDING THE TRACT SURVEY:
After the tract survey has been approved, the original shall be recorded in the
office of the recorder of deeds of Sangamon County, Illinois. If the tract
survey is not recorded within one hundred and eighty (180) days of Plats
Officer approval, the approval shall be null and void. (Ord. 2017-4, 3-21-2017)
